story: NewsFootage shows inside lurching British Airways flight trying to land in GibraltarFlight BA erted to Malaga as a precaution because of the extreme winds as it attempted to land in GibraltarShareCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video terrying-footage-board-british-airways-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShocking footage has emerged from the inside of a British Airways flight rocking and rolling from side to side as it attempts to land in Gibraltar. The video shows the Airbus A, which can hold more than  people, being thrown around by strong winds as it approaches the airport, with the wings dipping and lting by nearly  degrees as it tilts before it turns away. The pilot of flight BA, which left London Heathrow at roughly .am on Monday, erted to nearby Malaga as a precaution. A man who filmed the incident from the ground, who preferred not to give his name, said: Being where we are we see a lot of the landings, but never one as rough as that.  Glad that I wasnt on it! A British Airways spokesman said: The flight has landed safely and passengers have left the aircraft normally. Due to strong winds in the Gibraltar area, our pilots decided to land in Malaga as a precaution. The safety of our customers and crew is always our number one priority. One Gibraltar resident claimed she was on the flight and wrote online that it was very scary indeed.   Another watching the planes landing attempt from the ground said: “It was awful! “Never seen a plane rock from side to side as much! Scary. “I’m still shaken by it!”  Despite clear weather, wind speeds reached mph in Gibraltar today with stronger gales expected this evening. Gibraltar Airport is notorious for having dficult weather that causes turbulence. Pilots have to undergo special training to land there.

title: mum smothers burns baby back
story: NewsMum smothers and burns baby to get back at cheating boyfriendMarco Antonio Ticona Chiccalla, , claimed Lucero Oscava Burgos, , of Peru killed his daughterShareByLaura ForsythAna Lacasa:,  FEB NewsLucero Oscava Burgos, , after she was arrested with a police officer "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young mum has been arrested for killing and burning her -month-old daughter to get back at her cheating boyfriend. The incident is said to have taken place in the district of Manazo in the southern Peruvian department of Puno. It is here the tots father Marco Antonio Ticona Chiccalla, , claimed that his girlfriend killed his daughter. According to local media, police interrogated -year-old mum Lucero Oscava Burgos about the babys death. She initially claimed that her daughter had fallen out of bed and died. She said as a result she had buried the body by the River Hatun Mayu. Prosecutor Guadalupe Ramirez Mittani ordered the police to cordon off the area and carry out a search, however, they were unable to find the childs remains at the spot.  When they ed to question the mother, she admitted to suffocating her baby with a blanket before burning the body and dumping it in a grain silo, according to local media. She reportedly said that it was because Ticona Chiccalla was cheating on her with a workmate. The local authorities found the -month-old girl in the silo wrapped in blankets and partially burned, according to reports. The childs remains have been sent for an autopsy while the mother is being kept in police custody as the investigation continues.

title: dundee boss mcintyre ready to cross swords with new hibs gaffer heckingbottom
story: Jim McIntyre and Paul Heckingbottom will cross swords for the first time in their managerial careers when Dundee and Hibs clash at Dens tonight.However, while Jim admits to knowing little of his opposite number, his knowledge of the team he’ll be putting out means he’s not expecting too many tactical surprises.Hibs appointed Heckingbottom as the successor to Neil Lennon last week and he kicked off his time in Scotland with an Easter Road win over Hamilton Accies.While, in time, the Dee boss knows his opposite number will put his own stamp on the Hibees, right now he’s not expecting too many drastic tactical changes from the way they lined up under Lennon.“I don’t know him but he got off to a good start and Hibs have good players. It’s going to be a tough game,” said Jim.“He’s got good options as well, you need to be able to handle that.“We know what players he’s got to work with and we know their strengths and weaknesses like we do most of the other squads in the league. It’s about making sure yours are better than theirs on the night, that’s how it is in football.“We are back at home in front of the cameras and want to put on a good performance.”Dundee go into the game boosted by last week’s vital win at Livingston that hauled them out of the bottom two in the top flight for the first time since late August.Again, though, the manager is stressing it’s where the team are at the end of the season that counts.“We could be back down there come Saturdaywe don’t keep it going.“Livingston is gone now and now it’s all about this one.”

title: ive had so many great moments cafe in dundee city centre to close
story: A Dundee city centre cafe is due to close its doors by mid March.The Butterfly Cafe on Commercial Street, owned by husband and we Dom and Christine Anderson, will be closing on March .The cafe, first opened in , set out to encourage a play experience for children of all ages with Lego, action figures, dressing-up costumes, movies and games.Dom said in a y post on Facebook: “It is with a heavy heart that we wish to inform all of our wonderful customers that the decision has been made to sell the cafe.#This is for ious reasons and of course a decision that has not been made easily.#Dom, Christine, the whole team past  present want to thank every single one of you who has visited and particularly those who made us your second home, especially in the stressful first weeks of having a new baby.#We have loved getting to know you, your babies and children. It#s been a wonderful journey and one that won#t be forgotten.#Thanks to all our mums groups, the fantastic Pam and Jane from Peapod baby, amazing Ali and everyone at Nurture Parents who have enriched the lives of so many parents and children over the years.#Thank you for allowing us to watch your babies grow and allowing us to give them such a rich play experience at the cafe, especially all our Antenatal class parents, thank you all so much for making this the best three years, we can’t believe how much all these babies have grown up!#Hopefully when the cafe closes for the last time you will all be able to look back with fond memories and moments shared with your babies in our café, we’re truly unique and doubtful that there will ever be anywhere  quite like it, so please hold on to all those great times, from visiting Santa, building Lego, chilling out watching Batman, to first steps, making a mess and talking for the first time, we’ll remember forever.#From meI want to thank you for allowing my dream to come true, creating a welcoming safe space, especially to feed baby and relax with your children.#We did it! We made it happen, it worked, thank you for helping prove me right and proving that we are all in this together, as parents, it takes a village to raise a child and we’ve tried our best to help!#Keep building, keep laughing and remember play is the best cure for any upset or stress. I’ve had so many great moments and so many people to thank, our two wonderful children who have tidied the playroom more than anyone lol but most of all has been our brilliant staff who are really part of the family now. They are amazing, thank you.#Please be sure to visit us and let us share in these last moments with you, we want to stay as busy as possible until we close on the th March, so please visit us, take lots of photos and tag us in your memories.#

title: scott-bain-scorns-embarrassing-and-pathetic-motherwell
story: Scott Bain could take the title for the most laidback character in the Celtic dressing room but the affable goalkeeper was still incensed  hours after Motherwellrsquos controversial goal on Sunday afternoon.Ultimately it counted for little more than a statistical note but for the current incumbent of the number one shirt, it unravelled  domestic clean sheets and undone what he described as a considerable body of work in the process.Gboly Ariyibirsquos goal after Celtic had put the ball out for Ryan Christie to be treated for what looked like a hamstring pull was the first the Parkhead side had conceded domestically on their own turf since October.And Bain did not take the slight lightly.ldquoI think itrsquos pretty embarrassing, pretty pathetic that they felt they had to try that to score a goal, he said. ldquoIt was disappointing to lose the record like that. Not that we really thought or spoke about it but I donrsquot think we were too far away from getting to the record of clean sheets and wersquod got there by playing some very good football.ldquoItrsquos disappointing. Something Irsquove never seen before. Itrsquos a bit embarrassing to be honest. Irsquom sure they woke up on Monday morning and were a bit embarrassed of how theyrsquove handled it. They had the chance to recty the situation after and did nothing about it.ldquoThe amount of work that we put in to those games before with the clean sheets, the way we defendedhellip and itrsquos gone out of the window for something that shouldnrsquot really happen in football.ldquoFor us to come in and them to say lsquoyou won the game anywayrsquo hellip thatrsquos just absolutely pathetic.James Scott set the goal up when he latched onto a throw-in that Liam Grimshaw had put into the left channel. As play slowed anticipating a casual passing of the ball back, it quickly became apparent that the teenager was going for goal.Scott looked sheepish as he left the pitch later in the game, almost apologising to his bench, and Motherwell manager Stephen Robinson cited the inexperience of the player as the reason for the goal that flouted convention.Bain, though, was scornful of the reasons offered as he insisted that the responsibility for it ought to have been taken by the Motherwell management.ldquoTheir manager tried to blame it on a young lads but yoursquod got the chance to recty the situation after and they donrsquot do it, said Bain.ldquoI dunno. So, what has [Scott] not watched football before  Hersquos not played a game before  Youth team levels all the way up, it happens at every level. I thinkyou are the manager you have to recty the situation.ldquoI donrsquot understand what he was thinking. Hersquos tried to blame it on a young lad but hersquos in charge. So between him and the rest of the players they can sort it out. But obviously they didnrsquot want to. They wanted to try and get a second goal and get a point or go on to win the game.It will be interesting to note just what happens in the next fixtures between the sidesthere is a similar scenario of a player on either side requiring treatment. Bainrsquos fury was still simmering as he suggested that he would be playing tit-for-tat in any future matches, but that would seem unlikely given Brendan Rodgersrsquo is always at pains to stress a respect for opponents.Still, though,it was up to Bain there would be no such understanding.ldquoIf it was up to me  No. Not a chance, he said. ldquoIn future wersquoll probably just play with  men and not put the ball out of play. So our players could be lying down seriously injured. But it happened and we go from there.ldquoMost of the boys were angry and they have the right to be. It is not something we would do and it is not something I have seen anyone do, really. They have the right to be angry and for five or ten minutes it disjointed us a little bit and they came into the game but after the game against Valencia and how much all the boys put into that game and to power through again and get another two goals and win comfortably says a lot about the character in the team."

title: Climate action call comes to Inverness streets
story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. We could be on the brink of a mass extinction like the one which wiped out the dinosaurs.ldquoThe petition asked that the Highland Council... reverse inconsistent policies and work alongside the media to communicate with residents.The petition also called on the local authority to pass a climate emergency motion to make the region carbon neutral by .Fiona Cormie who has just taken on the role of co-ordinator of the group, said they hoped to add ldquosignicantly to its number of petition signatories in the coming weeks and present them to the council.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Disaled workers getting a raw deal new report claims
story: MANY disabled people in Scotland have been ldquofrozen out of work due to their condition, according to research by disability charity Leonard Cheshire.Three out of four said they left their jobs because they had not received the support they needed to fulfil their role, and nearly one out of five who applied for a job in the past five years felt the employer had chosen not to consider them for the post because they had a disability.Kenny Shand from Inverness who found himself in this situation, said: ldquoNot everyone is treated with respect. Whether you have additional support needs or not, the system needs to be more transparent. Workplace adjustments donrsquot need to be expensive ndash they just need to be done.Stuart Robertson, director at Leonard Cheshire in Scotland, said the findings lt the lid on a ldquotough and unwelcoming employment landscape.He said: ldquoMost people with disabilities in  remain frozen out of the world of work. All of us must redouble our efforts to challenge outdated attitudes to disability and accelerate the positive change that enables everyone to thrive in the world of work.The research also suggests more than half of all managers consider the cost of workplace adjustments a barrier to employing people with disabilities.In more promising news, Leonard Cheshirersquos research found a fth of employers say they are more likely to employ someone with a disability.The charity said the latest research shows an increased awareness amongst employers of the UK Governmentrsquos Access to Work scheme giving people grant and other support based on their needs, is up to  percent in  from  percent in .But many recipients are waiting more than three months for their application to be approved and the charity wants government action.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: First phase of 32m refurbishment completed at Inverness school
story: THE first phase of a major refurbishment programme at an Inverness primary school has been completed.Two new classrooms have opened at Smithton Primary, much to the delight of principal teacher Lynne Macdonald who said the new facilities increased opportunities for its  children as well as staff.Pupils have also got a new a multiuse games area.ldquoItrsquos made a huge dference, she said.ldquoIt gives us a lot more space and just little things like having blackout blinds on sunny days and having all the children in seats at the same height really helps.The pound. million refurbishment project to address the schoolrsquos current and future capacity needs began last April.Once completed, it will see a total of five additional classrooms created along with two support needs rooms, a dedicated space for senior pupils and an extended gym hall.Local councillor Trish Robertson said it was excellent to see the project start to take shape.ldquoThe expansion was badly needed and having the extra space must be better for the children, she said. ldquoIrsquom really pleased itrsquos gone up so quickly.Iain MacDonald, special works manager for Morgan Sindall, which is carrying out the renovation work, said construction was currently on track for completion by September.ldquoThe most important thing for us has been not to interrupt the daily activity of the school, he said.ldquoBut another big thing is giving the kids a good experience of construction ndash therersquos a perception that construction is about the trades but therersquos so much more to get involved in.Miss Macdonald added: ldquoThe workers have been great. They always make sure they receive any deliveries before am which really helps and means the construction isnrsquot impacting the children. Thatrsquos the most important thing.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Funding blow to Highland food banks charity
story: North-based charity Blythswood Care has issued a public appeal for more donations after it lost an annual pound, recycling grant from Highland Council in the recent local authority budget.The charity which has one of the largest networks of food banks in the Highlands handles around  tonnes of clothing donations a year at its Evanton depot of which more than  per cent was reused or recycled.Previously the council financially supported the recycling work and some local authority properties already host textile banks for taking unwanted clothing deposits but this year withdrew support.The council had to plug an almost pound million financial hole in its budget amid shrinking government grants for core services, the moves was called a ldquobody blow by operations manager Ian Matheson who admitted the loss of the recycling grant is not a complete surprise.ldquoWe recognise that the Council has been faced with hard decisions. Wersquove enjoyed a mutually beneficial partnership with Highland Council for over  years and we really appreciate that, he said.ldquoTheir support has enabled us to develop our re-use and recycling activities, reducing waste, providing local employment and raising support for projects such as Blythswoodrsquos Highland Food Bank.ldquoDonations of clothing, bric-a-brac and quality furniture from the general public are going to be more important to us than ever as we aim to continue this aspect of our work despite the loss of this grant.The organisation processes more than , tonnes of donations a year at its Evanton depot, producing goods for its charity shops and selling on to processors in other parts of the country.Mr Matheson said ldquoWe have to constantly review all that we do and consider what efficiencies we can make. You can help us now by giving our shops your custom and donations.ldquoAll donations will be gratefully received so we can have continuity of employment ndash because this is about jobs too ndash as well as maintain service provision.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoWe have had very positive discussions with Blythswood and these are ongoing about how we can possibly work together in the future.Blythswood welcomes donations of textiles, footwear, bric-a-brac, small electrical goods, books and good quality furniture.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Highland Council investing extra in roads maintenance
story: Highland Council is hoping an additional pound. million for maintenance announced as part of this yearrsquos budget will make a ldquonoticeable dference across the region.The funding, approved as a priority area for the revenue budget, will be shared out across Highland with area committees able to decide how to prioritise it more locally.Chairman of the councilrsquos environment, development and infrastructure committee, Councillor Allan Henderson, said: ldquoWe have the most extensive network of roads in the UK and, added to this, we are faced with some of the most severe weather conditions in the Highlands.ldquoThe freeze-thaw conditions in particular cause immense damage to road surfaces and this is very evident in the past few weeks.ldquoRoad conditions are a high priority for local residents and this was very clear in our recent engagement with communities and local representatives.ldquoThe additional resource will, I hope, make a noticeable dference and can be allocated to the roads with the most urgent need of repairs, right across the Highlands.Area allocations based on road mileage and population are:Badenoch  Strathspey: pound, Caithness: pound,Inverness: pound, Lochaber: pound, Nairn: pound,Ross  Cromarty: pound,Isle of Skye: pound,Sutherland: pound,Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Hotel plan for Inverness car park site
story: PLANS which would see a city centre car park transformed into a six-storey hotel have been unveiled.The pound million proposal by developer SRP Inverness Ltd was displayed to the public at the Spectrum Centre on Farraline Park, immediately next to the two-deck Rose Street car park which is earmarked as the site for the -metre high hotel.The proposal is the latest city hotel development from SRP Inverness directors Stewart Campbell and Stuart McCaffer, who were also behind the creation of the Inverness Encore Hotel, now the Pentahotel, on nearby Academy Street.Mr Campbell is confident the -bedroom L-shaped building will attract interest from a globally-known hotel brand, bringing something new to the Inverness accommodation mix.ldquoWe have worked with a number of global brands over the years, he said.ldquoInverness has massive global tourism and a lot of people, particularly global travellers, want the comfort of a well-known global brand.ldquoInverness is a strong tourism market, but therersquos been a lack of supply over the years. Other than the Travelodge on Academy Street in , there hasnrsquot been a new hotel built in Inverness since .The proposal includes a gym, three retail units within the hotel footprint and parking for  cars.Mr Campbell believes the hotel will benefit from its proximity to Inverness bus and railway stations, while any under capacity at the car park would be compensated by the nearby multi-storey car park.Mr Campbell and Mr McCaffer also own the neighbouring Rose Street Hall, which they hope to utilise for retail or restaurant use once the hotel is completed.Between the two, they also plan to construct a new bus and taxi road, replacing the footpath linking the bus station and Rose Street retail units.SRP Inverness expects to apply for planning permission in mid-April.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Opinion divided on how to tackle Inverness gull menace
story: TIDY streets could be a more effective deterrent to Invernessrsquos seagull menace than culling, according to the RSPB.The suggestion comes in response to a call for a limited cull by city businessman Charlie Barbour.Mr Barbour, who owns city centre bars The White House and The Dog House as well as commercial property agency Barbour Commercial, suggests that destroying a small number of nesting pairs would make the centre of Inverness more attractive, safer and quieter.Describing the birds as ldquonoisy, dirty, aggressive and a blight on the city centre, Mr Barbour questions whether the Inverness Business Improvement Districtpolicy of removing eggs each year is enough to permanently reduce the gull population.ldquoWhilst a cull of such birds is not a universally popular decision, I just wonderthere is merit in destroying say three or four nesting pairs of seagulls each year, he writes.ldquoA reduction in seagull numbers would improve the city centre experience for visitors and that surely has to be a good thing However, a spokeswoman for conservation charity the RSPB said that lethal control should only ever be a last resort, used only where there is a proven problem and other alternatives have proven ineffective. Instead, local authorities, businesses and iniduals should tackle the problem by reducing the birdsrsquo food supply by cutting down the amount of edible litter and introducing gull-proof litter bins.Other non-lethal options include putting up physical barriers such as netting on roofs as a deterrent before the breeding season.ldquoWe believe that gull problems in an urban environment are best tackled by reducing the availability of food and nest sites. If the features that attract gulls remain, any `vacanciesrsquo created by controlling existing gulls will simply be filled by other gulls moving in, she said.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Roads not safe for city cyclists says Inverness campaigner
story: A LOT needs to be done to bring roads in Inverness up to a standard that makes them safe and easy for road users to navigate, a leading cycling campaigner has said.Brian MacKenzie, convener of the Highland Cycle Campaign, said: ldquoI cycle a lot and there is no doubt the roads in the town are in very poor condition.ldquoThe trunk roads, too, need attention.Championing the cause for better and safer routes for cyclists he said drivers also need to be aware of cyclists and give greater consideration to them.ldquoDrivers often criticise cyclists when they see them weaving along certain routes but often they are doing that simply to avoid potholes and are taking evasive action, he said.ldquoAt the Raigmore Interchange, on the ramp joining the A south from the A, there is a pothole which has been there for some time. It is now gathering water and there is a warning sign for traffic alerting them to flooding.ldquoThere are also two more long potholes which are much more dangerous for cyclists and motorists just as you enter the interchange off the northbound ramp, coming from the Beechwood direction of the A.ldquoThe seal between the interchange and the ramp has gone andyou are cycling along there on a dark night you canrsquot see it, so your wheel can get caught up in it. These are like tram lines and they could throw you off a bike and cause serious injury.ldquoEvery vehicle coming from the A has to go across these potholes as they enter the interchange as well and they have been like that for a considerable time.ldquoI am wondering when the trunk roads people are going to carry out these repairs.While Highland Council is responsible for the upkeep of most roads in Inverness and the surrounding towns and villages, Bear Scotland is responsible for trunk roads.A spokesman for the organisation told the Courier last week that major defects, including deeppotholes which could pose a danger to road users, are repaired within  days, with safety inspections of all roads under its care inspected on a weekly basis.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Sugars night set to be sweet for Highland Hospice
story: AN evening of fun, quality entertainment and good food has been promised by an Inverness man who is raising money for the Highland Hospice.Alastair Kennedy, communications director at Global Energy Group and chairman of Nigg Skills Academy, is calling on local businesses to try and help with his fundraising for this yearrsquos Strictly Inverness dancing competition.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom hoping that the business community will support this amazing cause as they have done in the past.Known to his friends as Sugar, Mr Kennedy will be hosting a dinner called Sugarrsquos Strictly Big Night at the Kingsmills Hotel in Inverness on April .The black tie tartan event will consist of live music from local band Torridon as well as an auction, quiz and a raffle, with all proceeds going to the hospice.Mr Kennedy is reaching out to the local business community to come along and support the event so he can raise as much money as possible.The director of Ross County Football Club is well known for his enjoyable hosting of hospitality at their home matches over the past  years, and thinks he has the the expertise and dry sense of humour to host another entertaining and enjoyable evening for all.As the oldest ever competitor in Strictly Inverness, Mr Kennedy was inspired to get involved in this yearrsquos event after sadly losing his mother to cancer in . She spent her final days in the hospice.ldquoTheir facilities and the care they provided for my mum was just so wonderful and considerate, he said.ldquoThey looked after her so well in her last days with us. I said at the time that I must, at some point in the future, do something to raise much-needed funds for the hospice, and with it being their th Strictly anniversary year, I just thought maybe now is the time.ldquoThere are lots of couples competing for the Strictly Inverness title and there is already great camaraderie being built up between us all.ldquoThis is not so much about winning, itrsquos more about raising money for this most worthy cause and everyone is working so hard not just in dance training, but in raising money by whatever means. I am hoping my business connections will assist me in being able to create a great night, but also raise as much money as possible for the hospice.Tables cost pound for  people and anyone interested should contact Mr Kennedy via Global Energy Group.Strictly Inverness also raises money for Inverness Ice Centre, which hosts the showdown from May .Monday  Feb  : PM

title: aberdeen butcher installs second defib following community support
story: An Aberdeen butcher is to install a second defibrillator near his shop after receiving overwhelming support from the community.HS Milne and Sons in Bucksburn already has the vital le-saving piece of equipment set up outside its Inverurie Road branch but now, thanks to generous customers, provision will double in the area.The new defibrillator will be placed at Davy’s Fish Bar on Sclattie Park and has been bought thanks to the Butchers at the Heart of the Community initiative.The scheme, which is Scotland-wide, was set up by Hunters of Kinross and is supported by Scottish Craft Butchers, the Scotch Butchers Club and Save a Le Scotland.Its main aim is to help and encourage people to be ready and confident to use CPR equipment in the event of somebody suffering a cardiac arrest.Kenny Milne, owner of HS Milne and Sons, became involved with the scheme last summer.He said: “The community helped us raise money for the defibrillator which is outside the store.“It was installed in November. We originally only planned to install one but the money kept coming in and we had enough for another one so we spoke to Davy’s Fish Bar and they said they would back it.”The defibrillators can be purchased for around £, – a reduced price because they were bought in bulk through the Butchers at the Heart of the Community scheme.Both defibrillators will be accessibly to the public when needed.If an emergency  call is made and the defibrillator is registered with the Scottish Ambulance Service, the nearest device can be located and a code given to the caller to unlock it.Once opened, instructions are provided.For heart-attack victims, the community defibrillators could prolong their lives by vital minutes, because the more time that passes during a cardiac arrest without assistance, the less chance there is of survival.Mr Milne said he was overwhelmed by the community’s generosity.He said: “Most of it was raised in the shop. We also raised about £ through a Just Giving page.“Local musicians put together a concert at Newhills Church, and a second one at Bucksburn Church which raised quite a bit of money. It was all raised by the community.”The equipment is expected to be installed shortly.Douglas Scott, chief executive of Scottish Craft Butchers, said: “This project is all about enabling butchers to save the lives of people in their community, raising money to provide defibrillators and training staff on how to do CPR.”

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayrshire hospice marks 30th birthday
story: NewsAyrshire Hospice marks th birthday as staff and volunteers reflect on three decades of serviceThe milestone birthday has been marked with a series of events and celebrations.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFor  years it has touched the lives of thousands in Ayrshire and far beyond. Its mission  To enrich the remaining days of those facing le-limiting illness. The work of the Ayrshire Hospice, irreplaceable since February , has formed part of the region’s fabric over three decades. But at pound, per day to fund bosses admit they owe their biggest debt to the public. Reflecting on the landmark birthday, chief executive Mandy Yule said: “Our message to the wonderful people of Ayrshire is ‘thank you’. “We wouldn’t be able to deliver the level of care we doit wasn’t for their support. “We have an incredible group of volunteers and fundraisers across Ayrshire, some of whom have given their time for over  years, and without the fundraising efforts the hospice wouldn’t be here.” Since opening its doors on Racecourse Road the base has become a centre of care, comfort, compassion and dignity to more than , patients.  But its true origins go back even further to a group of hard-working volunteers who set up their own trust in . Their goal was to raise the necessary funds to open a hospice in Ayrshire. After as initial target of pound, was met within  months the next task of finding a suitable location threw up Racecourse Road. Building work began in  and, with it, the hospice service was launched with the appointment of two home care nurses. From its earliest days fundraising has served the heart of the hospice. And it is that invaluable support that the hospice – which has almost  staff and volunteers – is recognising during its th year.   Mandy said: “Because of their efforts we have access to some of the best palliative care treatments available, allowing us to give our patients comfort and quality of le. “We have been privileged to give thousands of patients and their families the care and support they need, both at the hospice itself or wherever they have lived in Ayrshire, over the last  years and we take great pride in that”. To help mark the anniversary a special memory tree has been created giving the opportunity to leave reflections and memories of the hospice. Mandy said: “We never take the compassionate and continued support of the hospice by the people of Ayrshire for granted. “The memory tree gives people the chance to leave their own memories or thoughts about the hospice and be part of our celebration.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr NewsAyr

title: jury asked convict ayr broadcaster
story: NewsJury asked to convict Ayr broadcaster Bryce Curdy on girl rape chargeHis defence claims evidence against him "doesnt stack up"ShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB NewsThe trial is taking place at the High Court in Glasgow "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA PROSECUTOR has urged a jury to convict broadcaster Bryce Curdy of raping a -year-old girl in the South of France. Liam Ewing told jurors: “You have heard how the girl described screaming as he raped her.” He added: “I ask you to examine the evidence. She goes into a lot of detail about what happened to her. I invite you toa guilty verdict.” The alleged victim, who is now , claimed that Curdy, , from Ayr, raped her three times. She alleged that on each occasion he whispered to her afterwards” If you tell anyone I will kill you and your mum.” Curdy, who is on trial at the High Court in Glasgow, denies raping her on ious occasions between April  and August , , at a house in the South of France. Mr Ewing told the jury that the Crown is relying on testimony from the girls mother, who is , to corroborate the rape. She alleges that Curdy also raped her in August  in the South of France. The mothers allegation, which he denies, is not before the jury. Under Scots Law alleged crimes against children committed in another country can be prosecuted here, but not those against adults. The mother claimed that after having consensual sex with her, Curdy went on to rape her. Defence counsel Lorenzo Alonzi told the jury: “If you apply the law, you will find that the correct verdict in this case is acquittal.” Mr Alonzi said in his closing speech that there was absolutely no independent evidence in this case – only the allegations of the girl and her mother. He went on: “There is no DNA evidence, there is no torn clothing, there is no medical evidence and no witnesses who heard screams. “The idea that there was this monstrous threat to kill her and her mum, it doesnt stack up.” Curdy claimed that the two woman made up the allegations about him after he demanded theof his pound, gold and diamond Rolex watch. The trial before judge Johanna Johnston QC continues.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSex crimeGlasgowAyrCourtsJusticeAyr News

title: malawi partners set top tour
story: NewsMalawi partners get set for top tour of AyrshireErnest Chirwa and Francis Juma from Bandawe All Girls Secondary School and Bandawe Primary School will embark on a tour of Ayrshire from March  - .ShareByAbi Smillie:,  FEB NewsFrancis Juma with Bill Duncan, Elder from Alloway Parish Church "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAlloway Parish Church are gearing up to welcome partnering head teachers from across the globe next month. title: volunteers bid breathe new life
story: NewsVolunteers bid to breathe new le into Ayr town centre with arts hubThe team behind the move say they will bring fresh ideas and creation to the towns bottom end.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA bid to breathe new le into Ayr’s emptying High Street will be staged by hard working volunteers. The group insist a “cultural hub” can spark much needed footfall at the town’s tired bottom end. And they hope a plan to rent the former clothing store, Millets, will aid their cause. FreshAyr, the team behind the project, are not new to opening ‘pop-up’ spaces in the town. But boss Robert Singer, , insists: “We believe this next phase is potentially our most important. “Ayr has lost its place as a market town and tourist destination. “Long gone are the factories, fisheries and agricultural markets of the past – even retail is failing. “So there is a serious pressing need to rethink the way people engage with High Streets. “Our project will focus on the arts and use it as a force for regeneration.” The team have won a three month ‘proof of cause’ deal which, they hope, will lead in turn to later funding.   Robert explained: “We have a five year project in mind with this unit ideally being our permanent base. “Until now, we have operated around the town on a pop-up basis but that is never ideal. “We’d like this as our home.” The ‘BREAD arts lab’ will launch next month and run in conjunction with the project’s bakehouse, which is set to operate from Cathcart Street.
