title: Iain Macwhirter  Get over it - cis women are just on the wrong side of history
story: This, apparently, is to educate heteronormative women about their ldquoprivilege ndash the fact that they can use the toilets, sorry ldquowashrooms, of their choice and access healthcare. Irsquom not sure who exactly has been preventing transgender women using public conveniences. So far as I know, you donrsquot have to show a birth certicate, or undergo a medical exam to have a pee. But what do I know as a pale, stale male.What I do know is that ldquocis-gender is an ugly neologism which many women find offensive. They are content with their present sexual terminology. ldquoCis is in the same linguistic ballpark as ldquoTERF ndash trans exclusionary radical feminist, which is a term of abuse used against women who believe persons with penises are, er, male. I should be careful here because a number of TERFS have been banned from social media for saying that a person with a penis is a man. So I wonrsquot say that.Instead, letrsquos just take it as read that in future we are going to have to accept that the concept of sexual dferentiation with which we have been living for thousands of years is finally being exposed as a malign transphobic hood. At any rate, the Scottish Government appears determined to press ahead with reform of the Gender Recognition Act, which will allow trans people to assign themselves legally and biologically female. Hitherto, trans people have had to undergo medical examination and get a diagnosis of ldquogender dysphoria. No more. From now on, anyone can change their birth certicate to whatever they wish.Earlier this month, Holyroodrsquos culture committee warned that ending binary ldquoMale or Female questions in the Scottish census will render much of the results meaningless and, willy nilly, import an unscientic definition of sex into the law. But the Scottish Government is not listening. Nicola Sturgeon told a UN equalities conference last week that the concerns of feminists about the GRA are ldquomisplaced.Women ndash sorry, ldquomenstruators ndash who say that self-ID erases their sexual identity will be told: just get over it. They can complain that ldquosex is a protected characteristic under the  Equalities Act, and that women therefore have a right to their own unique spaces. But now that men can actually become women under the law, this right will be impossible to articulate. Trans women with male anatomy will be entitled to enter womenrsquos changing rooms, girl guide troops or womenrsquos prisons. Women who complain will be guilty of transphobia, and are likely to be visited by the police recording a ldquohate incident.Now, I have nothing against adults changing their gender, or identying as women, queer, non-binary, intersex or whatever. It seems to be reinforcing outmoded concepts of gender to suggest that, because someone wants to wear dresses, play with dolls and put on makeup, they must have a lady brain in a male body. I thought we had left pink-for-girls gender stereotyping behind. But never mind. No-one wishes trans people any ill ndash certainly not me. But now that we are abandoning the very biological definition of sex, there are some anomalies that need to be addressed.Last week, a British transgender man, who had IVF by sperm donation and gave birth, won a court battle to prevent his child having ldquomother on its birth certicate. It will be the first child in history to have no mother. The The AIRE Centre, a human rights charity, contested this on the grounds that it would make le dficult for the child in future, when they apply for visas or anything which enquires about family background. The Government said simply that this isnrsquot a problem. From now on, fathers can give birth ndash end of.But Irsquom not sure this is the end of the matter. Children have not been included in the gender recognition debate thus far, even though they have rights too. It could be psychologically disturbing for a child to find, one day, that its mother has decided to become its dad. That song ldquoSometimes I feel like a motherless child takes on a whole new meaning.Of course, the trans parent will still be present, but is it OK to expect a child to suddenly start calling her natural mother her father  I would have thought that a child has a continuing right to a legal motherthey were born with one. If misgendering a trans person is unacceptable, surely demothering a child should be too. This is going to be confusing to say the least.Then there is the question of sport. The controversy over athlete Caster Semenya, a woman with high testosterone, raises the question of how to regard trans womenrsquos participation in women-only sport. Athletes who have testes, and therefore posses greater body mass, muscle strength and bone density, have an unfair advantage over old-fashioned women who have genetically female bodies.Next week, the International Association of Athletics Federations will argue in a hearing in Switzerland that people like Semenya should take testosterone-suppressing drugs before competing. Not only would this drive a coach and horses through the anti-doping protocols, it surely poses problem for transgender athletes who, of course, also take drugs like testosterone to help them transition to their ldquocorrect male sex. I hope the sporting authorities can get their heads around that because I canrsquot.Yet this is a very live issue in many sports. In the US, the ban on trans women taking part in power-lting events is being lted to prevent accusations of discrimination. You might have thought that having beefy, male-bodied women participating in these contests is discriminating against women athletes. Though, of course, only transphobes would say that, so we wonrsquot go there.The logical solution to this conundrum is to end sexual segregation in sport. Andwomen who are born biologically female never win any medals, tough. Strangely, there doesnrsquot seem to be the same issue about female-bodied trans men participating in male-only sport . Irsquom sure that has nothing whatever to do with the fact that they wonrsquot win anything.So welcome to the brave new world of post-sexual dferentiation, where men become women and fathers have children. It is one of the most radical and abrupt cultural changes in human history.Women have had a pretty bad deal in previous centuries, when they were regarded often as chattels without rights. In some Muslim societies theyrsquore still second-class citizens. Now, as women are finally emerging from the shadow of patriarchy, they are being told, by men, that they no longer have exclusive rights to their sexual identity.Itrsquos a weird turn of events. It seems women are just on the wrong side of history. But somehow, I donrsquot think theyrsquoll go quietly.

title: glasgow-gateway-to-scotland-the-best-charles-rennie-mackintosh-within-90-minutes
story: The striking beauty and modernity of the work was not fully appreciated in his letime, though the vision of its ambitious creator is now recognised and celebrated around the world. Brad Pitt, Barbra Streisand and Madonna are among Mackintoshrsquos fans, and his pioneering designs continue to influence popular culture, not least in film and television, where sci-fi classics such as Bladerunner, Inception, Doctor Who and Star Wars ndash Darth Vader sits on a Mackintosh-inspired chair in the Empire Strikes Back ndash paid tribute to his geometric style.Nothing, however, compares to seeing and experiencing Mackintoshs work in person, and Glasgow is the best place in world to do so. Sadly, his masterpiece, Glasgow School of Art, was devastated in a second fire last year, with the schoolrsquos management pledging to rebuild, though this will clearly take many years.Glasgow, Gateway to Scotland: The best film locationsThere have been more positive developments where, of course, not least the opening of Mackintosh at The Willow, the stunning restoration of the original Willow Tearooms building on Sauchiehall Street. In Dundee, meanwhile, the new VA Museum ndash a world-class celebration of Scottish and international design - has Mackintosh at its beating heart.ldquoToshie as he was known to his friends, remains an indelible presence in the west of Scotland, though sometimes even Glaswegians become complacent about their cityrsquos most creative son. But thanks to Mackintoshs extraordinary creativity across the mediums therersquos always something new and interesting to see, whether yoursquore being introduced to the work for the first time or are a lelong admirer. With this in mind, wersquove put together a list of the best places to experience Mackintosh this year, all within  minutes of Glasgow.Queens Cross ChurchStill something of an under-appreciated gem, the only church designed by Mackintosh showcases his early promise. The unfussy, gothic-inspired building sits inconspicuously at a busy urban intersection on the edge of Maryhill, between the city centre and Glasgowrsquos west end, and you might easily walk past. Those who go inside are in for a treat, however, as the fully-restored interior highlights not only Mackintoshs love for nature but his appreciation of all things Japanese - not to mention is sense of humour.A favourite place of the late Princess Margaret, the church is now the home of the Charles Rennie Mackintosh Society, and offers year-round workshops, seminars, exhibitions, walks and talks. Itrsquos also one of Glasgowrsquos most beautul, intimate and under-rated music venues and hosts a wide array of concerts and events throughout the year. Garscube Road, Glasgow. Entry: pound. Children free. MackintoshchurchScotland Street SchoolOne of the biggest and best-loved of all Mackintoshrsquos buildings, the school ndash designed between  and  ndash provides a double whammy in terms of visitor experience. As well as exploring the amazing architecture, you get the chance to explroe the history of Scottish education in the fantastic hands-on displays, exhibitions and live performances that are dotted around this eminently family-friendly museum. Scotland Street, Glasgow. Free entry. Glasgowle.org museumsGlasgow, Gateway to Scotland: The best whisky and BurnsKelvingrove Museum and Art GalleryArgyle Street, Glasgow. Glasgowle.org museumsHouse for an Art LoverDesigned as an entry to a prestigious German architecture competition, House for an Art Lover was conceived by Mackintosh in , but after being disqualied on a technicality, it was never built. Not in the architectrsquos letime, anyhow. The project was ambitiously resurrected in the s and the house finally opened in Glasgowrsquos south side,  years after its original conception, as country house, exhibition space, venue, cafeacute, restaurant and artistsrsquo studios, all set in beautul grounds. Dumbreck Road, Glasgow. Entry: pound pound.. Children under  go free. HouseforanartloverMackintosh at The WillowRe-opened last year in the citys Sauchiehall Street after an ambitious and meticulous poundm restoration, Mackintosh collaborator Kate Cranstonrsquos most iconic tea rooms provide a glorious insight into the pairrsquos creative partnership. Conceived as a complete work of art - a Gesamtkunstwerk - Mackintosh, alongside his we Margaret, designed every element of the building, inside and out, including furniture, wall decorations and accessories. But this is not a museum so much as a lively place to meet, eat, socialise and hold events. The afternoon tea is a delight.A new on-site visitor centre, staffed by volunteers, provides a wealth of information about the Mackintosh Cranston Macdonald legacy in Glasgow.- Sauchiehall Street. MackintoshatthewillowGlasgow, Gateway to Scotland: The best film locationsThe LighthouseMackintoshrsquos first public commission was originally designed in  for The Herald, but since  it has housed event spaces, a cafe, Glasgowrsquos Centre for Architecture and Design, and a permanent exhibition and learning centre dedicated to its architect. The rooftop viewing area also provides some of the most spectacular views in the city.The Lighthouse, Mitchell Lane, Glasgow. Entry free.The Mackintosh HouseArguably nowhere better showcases Mackintoshrsquos genius as an interior designer than this wonderful recreation of the house he shared in the West End of the city, right next to the University of Glasgow, with Margaret.Featuring a meticulous reassembly of the principal apartments of their now demolished home in nearby Southpark Avenue, the apartments are filled with their original furniture and highlight the strikingly modern decorative vision shared by this remarkably modern couple.The Mackintosh House at the Hunterian, University of Glasgow. Entry: pound pound. Under s go free.VA DundeeBuilt on the banks of the Firth of Tay in Dundee, renowned Japanese architect Kengo Kuma ndash himself an acolyte of Mackintosh - has created a dramatic, beautul and entirely al base for Scotlandrsquos first dedicated design museum, with Mackintosh at the centre.Fully restored after half a century in storage, the magnicent Oak Room ndash the centrepiece of Miss Cranstonrsquos Ingram Street Tea Rooms in Glasgow ndash has been installed as the permanent centrepiece of the Scottish Design Gallery, on loan from Glasgow Museums.Riverside Esplanade, Dundee. Vam.ac.ukGlasgow, Gateway to Scotland: The best whisky and BurnsHill House, HelensburghThis ldquohome for the future in Helensburgh, an hour north west of Glasgow, is a particular favourite with many Toshie fans. Built for publisher Walter Blackie in , it is his domestic masterpiece and features many of the most recognisable designs and schemes, including the rose mot stencils.Problems with the exterior harling have always plagued the building, leading to water damage, and owners the National Trust for Scotland are currently building a ldquobox" around the house to protect it until a long-term solution can be found.Hill House is closed while the box is constructed, but will re-open to visitors in late spring.Upper Colquhoun St, Helensburgh. Entry pound. pound.. nts.org.ukMackintosh Club, HelensburghAnother Helensburgh gem is the Mackintosh Club, designed in  and now a hub for art, architecture and music.Sinclair Street, Helensburgh, G SU. Entry: pound. Mackintosh.clubDaily Record BuildingDesigned in  and tucked away from the bustle in a city centre lane, Mackintoshrsquos commission for the Daily Record now houses hip bar, cafe and music venue Stereo, and is a must-see stop on any city centre walking tour. Look upwards and you will see the striking use of colour on the faccedilade, which skilfully combines sculpted sandstone and white glazed bricks to maximise light. Listen carefully and you can almost hear the clack of the typewriters.Renfield Lane, Glasgow.Glasgow, Gateway to Scotland a partnership between People Make Glasgow and Glasgow Airport, in association with The Herald, aims to attract more US visitors and capitalise on a recent growth in overseas tourists by highlighting the cityrsquos position as both a must-see destination in itself, and the ideal base for accessing Scotlandrsquos landscapes, history and culture.Delta flies direct to Glasgow from JFK www.delta.United flies direct from Newark www.united.

title: Rosemary Goring  Now is the time for the Catholic Church   s own Reformation
story: For this book Martel has conducted more than , interviews in the Vatican City in Rome, and across the world. He has spoken to priests, cardinals, bishops, monsignors, papal ambassadors, seminarians and the Swiss Guard. His conclusion, which will shock some and come as no surprise to others, is that about  per cent of the clergy in the Vatican state are gay. In other words, the HQ of a church that will not bless same-sex relationships, and forbids its clergy to have sex lives, is riddled with hyprocisy at its very core.Of these  per cent, Martel writes, some are celibate or in denial, others are living with their partners, or resort to prostitutes. A rule of thumb is that the more vehemently a cleric condemns homosexuality, the more likely he is to be in the closet himself. Hence the behaviour of the Colombian cardinal, Alfonso Lopez Trujillo. He was in the vanguard of the churchrsquos mission to prevent gay marriage. As the dire consequences of the Aids epidemic became clear, contrary to commonsense and compassion, he refused to encourage the use of condoms. Here was someone eager to be seen to uphold traditional values. Yet Martel claims that Trujillo, who died in , used male prostitutes.There are examples closer to home, among them the late Cardinal Keith OrsquoBrien, who pursued a similarly denunciatory anti-gay agenda, despite his own homosexuality and predatory behaviour. In fact, it doesnrsquot matter where you look. Throughout the Catholic churchrsquos parishes, globally and locally, there has been the mother of all cover-ups, not just in the buttoned-up past, but right now, here, today.You could say the church has been built on lies: countless men forced to hide who they really are, or to seek refuge in an all-male environment where they could find illicit love behind closed doors. Those clergy who were straight must have found themselves in a bewildering labyrinth of duplicity. That such depths of deceit have been allowed to thrive says all you need to know about the controlling power of those at the heart of the church.Martel believes that Pope Francis has earned enemies by adopting a very untypical approach. ldquoWho am I to judge  he replied, when askedhe condemned homosexuals, thereby loosening the ground beneath the feet of those in the Holy See who donrsquot want their secrets aired, or their way of le altered.The revelation of such widespread double standards is an echo of the medieval churchrsquos calamitous abuse of power and wealth. Out of it has sprung a culture where bullying, intimidation and blackmail have flourished. Andthat has been going on in this sphere, you can be sure it will have spilled over into every other part of the churchrsquos affairs.In the wake of the revelation of child abuse on a grand scale in the church, you begin to see why hiding the truth was the default position. This is not to make a link between homosexuality and child abuse but to see why the ecclesiastical authorities were so quick, and adept, at making the problem disappear. In avoiding scandal, they were intent on protecting their own rather than those who had been so grievously harmed.With evidence of institutionalised deception of the extent Martel claims, the church brings shame on itself: not for the numbers of priests who are gay, but for the willingness to lie about it, and to break vows, and the spirit of vocation, to an extent that will appall devout parishioners.Now is the time for the Catholic Churchrsquos own Reformation. No-one can any longer doubt that the le expected of a Catholic priest is unhealthy. And since there is no biblical injunction on him to be celibate, why can this not be changed  Already the church is embracing married Anglican vicars in flight from the ordination of women. Why not allow Catholic clergy the same right to open relationships, whether they be gay or straight Until the double-speak on which the modern church stands is addressed, there is no hope of winning back the faithful who have lost all trust and respect in this once revered institution. Obliging men to profess one thing while being another, is psychological torment. The denial of clergyrsquos humanity and self-expression is as cruel as anything the Inquisition devised. If the Vatican could bring itself to accept homosexuality, and gay marriage, and a non-celibate priesthood, it would be a truly Christian act.Read more: Cardinal Keith OBrien asked for forgiveness

title: students-sign-open-letter-to-call-for-review-into-universal-credit
story: The group say UC has ldquofundamentally disregarded students in the way it calculates their income, with lone parents, the disabled and students from low income families among the hardest hit.Paloma Paige, president of the St Andrews University Studentsrsquo Association, is the main signatory of the letter and warns of the long-term impact on access to education.She said: ldquoThe effects on student claimants puts widening access and ersity initiatives at risk. It is simply unacceptable that some of our most vulnerable students are left behind by a policy which should be supporting them.UC is the supposed flagship reform of the benefits system, uniting six lsquolegacyrsquo benefits - including tax credits, housing benefit and unemployment benefit - into one paid monthly, but it has proved hugely controversial. Designed to simply the system, but has proved hugely controversial, with many saying they are worse off and at a greater risk of hunger, debt and rent arrears.According to the National Union of Students , those who claim UC are harder hit than those who work, as for every pound that someone earns through work, they see p deducted from their monthly payments.However, for students who claim UC, their loans and grants are regarded as unearned income and therefore untaxed, so for each pound they receive, they lose the same amount from their claim.In the letter, signed by students from universities including St Andrews, Edinburgh, Glasgow, Stirling and Dundee, they state: ldquoMany students are now finding themselves in a position where it is becoming increasingly dficult to maintain their place at university or colleges up, while trying to keep roofs over their heads and feed and clothe their families. This is particularly true for lone parent students, students with low-income families and disabled students. This is down to Universal Credit and how it deducts student income.ldquoUniversal Credit is the benefit that we are constantly being told is designed to lsquomake work payrsquo, but claimants are finding this is not the case, especially students. Does putting in a full-time working week at university not count as work  Under legacy benefits such as tax credits student income is not taken in to account, allowing families to still receive child tax credit alongside their student loan which would go a long way to helping offset the costs of raising a family, but because Universal Credit classes student income as unearned income it is taken into account and deducted pound for pound, leaving many claimants with no award or very little.The letter adds that the system will ldquostop disadvantaged students taking up places at university that they have worked incredibly hard for and calls on the government to review how students are impacted, adding: ldquoIf this is allowed to continue then we are potentially denying our country of seeing some of our best and brightest from fulfilling their potential and this in turn will have a knock-on effect for universities, who will start to notice a decrease in their student intake.ldquoWhat does this say for the future of our world-renowned university system and research hubs that play such an important part in the world stage  This does not look like the meritocratic society we are told we live in.The open letter calls on the government to review how students are impacted ldquoto allow for more support and to allow families to lt themselves out of the trap of poverty and low paid jobs.It states: ldquoSurely it is in the governmentrsquos interests to re-evaluate thisthey truly want to reduce child poverty, increase upward mobility and prove that we are not the socially closed society that it is increasingly looking like.Ms Paige, who has been campaigning on the issue in her role as president, said the situation at the moment is ldquounacceptable.She said last night: ldquoUniversal Credit has fundamentally disregarded students in the way it calculates student income. This has been felt by students and their representatives across the country, as the -plus signatories of this letter demonstrate.One St Andrews student, Sandra Mitchell, a -year-old single mother, said that after she started her history and inity course at St Andrews, she lost about pound a month in benefit money.Ms Mitchell, from Dundee, said: ldquoIrsquom the only person in the household who brings in any income. Irsquom left with just my student income as I donrsquot get any universal credit. Under the previous system I wouldrsquove still received child tax credits but under the new system Irsquove lost out on that.ldquoIt means that itrsquos very dficult to focus on your studies when yoursquore constantly worrying about finances, when you take into account your travel, your lunches, and books that can be very costly.A DWP spokesman said: ldquoIf people make a choice to move into education then it follows that they move across to the financial system students use, including maintenance grants and loans. Student loans are designed to financially support students and the maintenance element is classed as lsquounearned incomersquo for Universal Credit. pound of the loan is disregarded per month and Universal Credit also disregards elements paid for specic additional costs, such as tuition or books.

title: Marianne Taylor  Last chance for Mundell to put country before party
story: The majority of these demands are perfunctory, of course, made in the knowledge and expectation that they will be ignored by the target, while playing well with the initiatorrsquos supporters.The craziness of the last few months has precipitated a flurry of genuine and warranted resignation demands, however, which under normal political circumstances would have resulted in multiple ministerial heads rolling in any other era the Prime Minister would have been forced out long ago.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysAnother case in point is Scottish Secretary David Mundell, whose stubborn insistence on being ineffectual in the face of the biggest crisis this country has faced in generations is matched only by that of Jeremy Corbyn. Mr Mundellrsquos wan smiles and empty words about doing the best for Scotland as the Government he is a member of readies itself to push us off the no-deal Brexit clf, is as astonishing as it is appalling. He, too, should have gone months ago, not least over the manner in which his party has arrogantly steamrollered over the views and interests of the country he supposedly represents.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitRemarkably still in post, Mr Mundell now has one last chance to make a meaningful contribution to the ridiculous and dangerous situation the Westminster parliament has created for itself. The SNP is right to call for Mr Mundell to show some mettle and make clear that he will not serve in a Government that is willing to take us out of the European Union without a deal, a situation that would put the already fragile Scottish economy on the road to ruin. As the Scottish Secretary is well aware, businesses will fail, jobs will be lost and real people will suffer the sort of real hardships that will be dficult to recover from.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysSNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford has written to Mr Mundell, laying out the gravity of the situation and calling on him to back growing cross-party demands to halt the Brexit process by extending Article  and making clear to his boss, Theresa May, that he will resign unless she faces up the extremists in her party and takes no-deal off the table.At this critical juncture, the least that the people of Scotland deserve from the man who represents them at Cabinet level is honesty about where his loyalties lie: will he put country or party first  Mr Mundell, it really is that simple.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitOf course, Mr Blackfordrsquos letter also highlights the bleakness of the dilemma facing the SNP. If Mrs May gets her way and Parliament is faced with a last-minute binary choice between her terrible deal - which deprives us of the key benefits being in the EU - and an even more catastrophic no-deal, it leaves the party in a dficult position. How should Nicola Sturgeon instruct her MPs to vote in this scenario  Backing Mrs Mayrsquos ldquomy way or the highway deal would be criticised by many as a U-turn of epic proportions and a sign of weakness. Not voting for it, and thus facilitating a no-deal Brexit, would likely be viewed by many voters as unforgivable, leaving the party open to allegations that this is the outcome it has been secretly hoping for all along, in order to boost support for independence.Ms Sturgeon and her colleagues will be hoping the growing number of Tory ministers and backbench MPs ndash including Cabinet secretaries Amber Rudd, Greg Clarke and David Gauke - poised to revolt against their leader should she refuse to rule out a no-deal Brexit, will come to their rescue in the frantic days and weeks to come.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysThe emergence of the The Independent Groupmay also end up helping the SNPrsquos predicament, at least in the short term. Formed last week when eight MPs resigned from Labour unhappy at Mr Corbynrsquos disastrous leadership, it did not initially appear to be an important development. But when three Tory MPs also resigned and joined up, using the moment to launch a blistering attack on Mrs Mayrsquos disastrous Brexit strategy and their partyrsquos lurch to the right, it started to feel more signicant.What binds these MPs from dferent sides of the House of Commons is dismay at the drt of both parties to the extremities. title: marianne-taylor-last-chance-for-mundell-to-put-country-before-party
story: The majority of these demands are perfunctory, of course, made in the knowledge and expectation that they will be ignored by the target, while playing well with the initiatorrsquos supporters.The craziness of the last few months has precipitated a flurry of genuine and warranted resignation demands, however, which under normal political circumstances would have resulted in multiple ministerial heads rolling in any other era the Prime Minister would have been forced out long ago.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysAnother case in point is Scottish Secretary David Mundell, whose stubborn insistence on being ineffectual in the face of the biggest crisis this country has faced in generations is matched only by that of Jeremy Corbyn. Mr Mundellrsquos wan smiles and empty words about doing the best for Scotland as the Government he is a member of readies itself to push us off the no-deal Brexit clf, is as astonishing as it is appalling. He, too, should have gone months ago, not least over the manner in which his party has arrogantly steamrollered over the views and interests of the country he supposedly represents.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitRemarkably still in post, Mr Mundell now has one last chance to make a meaningful contribution to the ridiculous and dangerous situation the Westminster parliament has created for itself. The SNP is right to call for Mr Mundell to show some mettle and make clear that he will not serve in a Government that is willing to take us out of the European Union without a deal, a situation that would put the already fragile Scottish economy on the road to ruin. As the Scottish Secretary is well aware, businesses will fail, jobs will be lost and real people will suffer the sort of real hardships that will be dficult to recover from.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysSNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford has written to Mr Mundell, laying out the gravity of the situation and calling on him to back growing cross-party demands to halt the Brexit process by extending Article  and making clear to his boss, Theresa May, that he will resign unless she faces up the extremists in her party and takes no-deal off the table.At this critical juncture, the least that the people of Scotland deserve from the man who represents them at Cabinet level is honesty about where his loyalties lie: will he put country or party first  Mr Mundell, it really is that simple.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitOf course, Mr Blackfordrsquos letter also highlights the bleakness of the dilemma facing the SNP. If Mrs May gets her way and Parliament is faced with a last-minute binary choice between her terrible deal - which deprives us of the key benefits being in the EU - and an even more catastrophic no-deal, it leaves the party in a dficult position. How should Nicola Sturgeon instruct her MPs to vote in this scenario  Backing Mrs Mayrsquos ldquomy way or the highway deal would be criticised by many as a U-turn of epic proportions and a sign of weakness. Not voting for it, and thus facilitating a no-deal Brexit, would likely be viewed by many voters as unforgivable, leaving the party open to allegations that this is the outcome it has been secretly hoping for all along, in order to boost support for independence.Ms Sturgeon and her colleagues will be hoping the growing number of Tory ministers and backbench MPs ndash including Cabinet secretaries Amber Rudd, Greg Clarke and David Gauke - poised to revolt against their leader should she refuse to rule out a no-deal Brexit, will come to their rescue in the frantic days and weeks to come.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysThe emergence of the The Independent Groupmay also end up helping the SNPrsquos predicament, at least in the short term. title: history-detectives-ask-where-did-the-picts-go
story: But now a long-running project to shine a light on the Dark Age Picts of north-east Scotland has found that, far from being backward natives on Europersquos fringes, they were a sophisticated people with a developed culture whose reach stretched to the eastern shores of the Mediterranean and beyond.For six years the Northern Picts Project, which is mostly run by the University of Aberdeen, has been probing the secrets of one of Caledoniarsquos earliest people to expand upon their place in Scotlandrsquos story.The Picts arose around the third century AD to dominate parts of north-east Scotland, Orkney and Shetland until they mysteriously disappeared around  AD, leaving behind only a written record of their kings, scattered archaeological remains and strange carved stones dotted around the land.Even the name they called themselves has been lost, as Roman writers dubbed them Picts because of their habit of painting, or likely tattooing, their bodies.Roman versus Picts reanactments are popular to this dayThe Scotland they knew was a dferent world compared to the modern one.Wolves and bears still roamed in wild lands and elk and boar could be hunted in the forests.People were chiefly organised into scattered farming and fishing communities, and society was only just leaving its tribal past behind.Over time, myths have grown up around the Picts, such as the claim of the ancient writer Bede, who insisted the Picts were descended from Scythian tribes who migrated from the shores of the Black Sea.Professor Gordon Noble, who heads up the Aberdeen University project, explained that the lack of written sources makes the period dficult to study.: The mysterious isle where sickPicts went to be healedHe said: ldquoYou can take what Bede says with a lot of salt. We do not have a huge amount of knowledge of the Picts in terms of historical sources and what we do have is mostly from external ones.ldquoTherersquos late Roman writings and Irish and Anglo-Saxon sources but all we have from the Picts themselves is the lsquoking listrsquo.ldquoThey are most likely a collection of the Iron Age tribes which lived in Scotland at the time slowly coming together to form a cohesive kingdom.The project set out to investigate sites close to long-standing symbol stones to carry out fresh excavations in the hope of forming a better understanding of this mysterious people.A major discovery was made at Rhynie in Aberdeenshire, a landlocked village south of Huntly on the A, where eight carved Pictish stones ndash among them the carved ldquoRhynie man and the Craw Stane ndash had long been known about.The Rhynie man stone carvingArchaeologists now believe the site was home to a major royal enclosure comprised of several buildings, one of them constructed from massive curved oak beams, surrounded by a wooden wall four to five metres high.But it was fragments from Roman vases known as amphorae recovered in digging work which provided the most tantalising clue to the reach of the Picts.Vase pieces have been found at only three other sites in Scotland, including Dumbarton Rock, the seat of the ancient rulers of the Kingdom of Strathclyde.:Secrets of the Picts rise from the ashes of Viking raidThose found at Rhynie indicate it may well have been the dwelling place of a high-status Pictish ruler whose world stretched far beyond the north-east.The few records that remain also suggest the Picts may have had a far more unied kingdom than their neighbours to the west, organised along lines seen in Europe and to the south in England.Mr Noble said: ldquoRhynie is the most northern site these fragments have been found at, and they show that the Picts were part of a trading network which stretched far and wide into the Roman world.ldquoThe Picts are quite unusual in having an over-kingship of such an extensive area. In Ireland at this time therersquos more than  or so petty kings ruling very small kingdoms but what we see in Pictland is something thatrsquos a lot more like the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms.ldquoThese are not a people on the edge of Europe but one thatrsquos developing like its southern and eastern neighbours.ldquoThere are influences of western art and a great deal of commerce. The Picts are very much a part of wider European developments.:Dig may unlock secrets of ancient Pictish carvingMore recently, the projectrsquos archaeologists probed the symbol stones themselves and concluded they contain writing as well as art. Crucially, they claim, this developed in the third century and was likely influenced through contact with the written word of the Romans.It is now believed the symbols carved into the stones were a form of naming system that communicated the identities of Pictish people and places and are the last surviving fragments of their language.A Pictish symbol stone discovered in the River Din near DyceMr Noble said: ldquoThese stones occur at prominent places in the land and on Christian Cross slabs on graves, most likely telling something about the personrsquos rank and identity. They were probably developed in a similar way to Ogham script in Ireland and Scandinavian runes.While the Northern Picts Project has gone a long way to re-evaluating their place in Scottish history, much still needs to be done to flesh out the picture.Current work centres on a large fort at Burghead on the Moray coast. This site, which was destroyed in the ninth century, may hold clues to the eventual fate of the Picts.While there is evidence of a slow merging with the western kingdom of the Gaels, the people of the north-east were facing a new threat: the Vikings.Mr Noble added: ldquoThe Vikings were bad news for just about everybody in this period. But therersquos still much we need to know before we can say where the Picts went.

title: tv-review-is-the-new-bbc-scotland-channel-magic-or-mince
story: Three, two, one went the countdown and there was Chvrches singer Lauren Mayberry singing a number which would not be out of place in the next Bond film. Programming proper began, oddly, with A Night at the Theatrehosted by Iain Stirling, the voice of Love Island, the ITV reality show infamous for the thickness of the contestants and the thinness of the sheets under which they have sex on camera.ChVrches and SSO open new channelIf you know who Stirling is then you are probably the target demographic of the new channel. If not, then you, like me, are part of the fuddy duddy majority, those who sit down to an eveningrsquos viewing as we would a meal, consuming one programme after another till wersquove had enough, or the wine runs out. The Love Island lot are the take away set, snacking on ldquocontent" whenever and wherever they choose, either on social media or iPlayer.Whatever your age, the only thing worse than A Night at the Theatre would have been an afternoon in surgery. Tired, unfunny and peppered with audience participation games, it made The Good Old Days look like Sinatra at the Sands.        name : ballot,target: ballot_,params:.pushSTV, which closed down last year after failing to attract enough viewers, was run on pound million a year, bawbees in TV terms. BBC Scotland has pound million, but from that sum, which would buy three and a bit hours of Netflixrsquos The Crown, it has to fund  hours of programmes. Getting Hitched Asian Stylegave a hint of how the new channel would make the pennies stretch. A documentary about wedding planners Saffron Events, it had good talkersand some mild drama , but it was baggy and repetitive, just about it making it to an hourrsquos worth of material. There are two more parts to come. Is there really more to say YouTube star on new seriesThe Peoplersquos Newsgave people the chance to, er, give us their views on the news. There was one official taxi driver on it, and lots of people who could have been taxi drivers so in love were they with the sound of their own voices. A little bit Gogglebox, and accompanied by a head-splitting soundtrack, the hipsters at Channel  news will be kicking themselves they did not think of this first.At last, a proper event for event TV: the first episode of the final series of Still Game . With the dreadful timing of the Scotland football squad, the gang have found their form again when it no longer matters. The story about Jack and Victor entering the YouTube age was about as original as jokes about cat videos, but it left plenty of room for what SG does best: daftness laced with cyanide-strength sarcasm Burnistoun Tunes Inwas patchy, but some of the old stuff still works a treat. The nightrsquos final offering was the brilliant documentary Nae Pasaran , about a boycott by Scots engineers that curbed Pinochetrsquos bombing of his own people. Running it earlier would have given the channel a stamp of quality and seriousness, which it needed.Tutti Frutti is backLast night was supposed to be about the thrill of the new,there is such a thing any more in a multichannel world, yet there was something familiar about the evening. It took a while to pin down, then it came to me. The widely-trailedof favourite shows that inevitably struggled to live up to expectations, lots of familiar faces, a whf of prissiness. Yes, it was Hogmanay TV, but on a Sunday in February. BBC Scotland director Donalda MacKinnon has said the channelrsquos goal is "success over time". Consider the clock ticking.

title: umunna-sets-sights-on-tig-leadership-as-labour-and-tories-braced-for-more-defections
story: Today, TIG, as it has become known, prepares to hold its inaugural meeting and, as it does so, the leaderships of the Labour and Conservative parties are bracing themselves for more defections.Mr Umunna, who represents Streatham in London, is one of eight ex-Labour MPs who have joined forces with three former Tories to create the new centrist force in the Commons.Askedhe was going to be TIGrsquos leader, the -year-old politician told Sky News Sophy Ridge on Sunday: "Im clear I want to play the biggest role in this group and one of the things about the way we operate is the recognition that were all leaders."Mr Umunnas comments came as his former colleague Barry Gardiner, the Shadow International Trade Secretary, accused him of quitting Labour to join TIG because he knew he could never become leader of his former party."It was fairly clear to me the reason he wanted to leave the Labour Party was that he knew he could never lead the Labour Party," Mr Gardiner told the same programme. "This is about personality."Mr Ummuna has claimed the current party system is "broken" and has spoken in favour of proportional representation.He added: "Were quite clear that we believe that we should have the closest possible relationship with the European Union because were internationalists."We believe that the inidual should be given a  to succeed, that we have inidual responsibilities ourselves and people dont want their lives to be run by the state, that they would support education, infrastructure and the health service but also we believe, ultimately, that work is an incredibly important value and we need to give people a level of security that they expect."Now none of the established parties are providing the answers to those challenges."The former Shadow Business Secretary continued: "If within our group we are capable of forming a consensus around policies when we get to that point, then we have a much better chance of coming up with something that can unite our ided nation."Mr Umunna claimed Labour had become ldquounbearable and, commenting on anti-Semitism within the party, said: "I blame Jeremy Corbyn but I also blame other people who have acted as bystanders."It is disgraceful that the Shadow Cabinet has not done more, not been more vocal, not demanded more, not threatened to resign over what has been going on over anti-Semitism and the problem is, its too easy to choose an easy le because there is a rule by fear."Meanwhile, his TIG colleague Heidi Allen, a former Conservative MP, speaking about the roll-out of the Governments flagship new benefits system Universal Credit, told BBC Ones The Andrew Marr Show: "It could be the most phenomenal benefit system out there but, at the moment, its treating people not like human beings, just like a sausage machine."Askedthe group would become a political party, the Cambridgeshire MP replied: "Yes, thats the hope, absolutely."**Responding to an assertion over the weekend by Emily Thornberry that TIG should be crushed, TIG MP Luciana Berger said such comments led her to believe she had made the right decision to quit Labour.ldquoActually, thats the culture of a politics that Im leaving behind, declared the Liverpool MP, adding: ldquoWe should be operating in an open way, in a tolerant way, that that is what in the st century the country deserves."

title: the-school-where-record-numbers-of-pupils-study-home-economics
story: Sally Cameron, health and technology teacher at St Margaretrsquos, said home economics had been given a radical overhaul with a change of name, a new focus to lessons and the introduction of taster sessions in surrounding primary schools.She said: ldquoWe donrsquot call ourselves home economics. We changed because we felt it was an outdated term and did not reflect the work that is going on in schools.ldquoIn the first three years we teach topics such as the relationship between food and health and how food can prevent or cause dietary diseases.ldquoWe are educating the pupils on how to be clever consumers so they are aware of the labelling on food, packaging and advertising and we also look at other factors such as whether foods are free range or organic.Pupils also learn to cook, with popular lessons focusing on creating healthy versions of their favourite foods such as low-fat pizzas, fruit kebabs or chicken nuggets that are baked rather than fried.Getting families on board is also a key part of the strategy, with parents and grandparents invited to attend school to see for themselves how the subject has changed.Mrs Cameron said: ldquoWe want to enthuse parents when their children are still young so we invite families to learning evenings where we tell them the subject is no longer just about cooking and sewing.ldquoIt is an academic subject that can get pupils into university, college and the world of work as well as giving them valuable skills for le.

title: letters-snp-claims-on-local-authority-cash-dont-add-up
story: Am I alone in questioning her logic on this  If local authorities really are getting ldquomore money, as the SNP leadership insists, why are real councils in the real world having to cut such important services in the face of growing need for those services  It makes no sense, particularly as the Scottish Government got a small increase in its allocation for this year. Why are councils getting cuts when there is more money in the pot In my experience the only people who are taken in by this are SNP politicians, in particular SNP councillors, who will happily whistle the ldquomore money theme as a musical accompaniment, while casting their votes to cut vital services for their own constituents. As that other nationalist, Margaret Thatcher, once said, "its a funny old world".Alex Gallagher,Labour Councillor Ward , North Ayrshire Council, Phillips Avenue, Largs.NICOLA Sturgeon took great delight, at the latest First Ministers Questions, to use one of her favourite ripostes to the opposition. When challenged over her ldquolack of spending" in certain areas she replied that there was no money left, therefore any changes must be matched by a loss of finance where in the system. Now she is facing a potential teachers strikewhere she has to come up with more money to avert this outcome.This leaves Ms Sturgeon with her own dilemma. If the financial offer to the teachers is raised, perhaps she will also inform the public where the consequent cut in services will come. If she does not give the teachers more money, she will have created a very damaging strike at a very sensitive time in the school calendar. Its Sturgeons choice.Dr Gerald Edwards,Broom Road, Glasgow.CATRIONA Stewart has some fun at the expense of those getting agitated about our First Minister taking time out to tour North America, quickly followed by a trip to France . In normal circumstances she would be right to defend the right of Scotlandrsquos leader to travel abroad promoting Scotlandrsquos best interests, but of course the circumstances are anything but normal, and from the content of Nicola Sturgeonrsquos speeches it was very clear that on this occasion promoting Scotlandrsquos business interests abroad was far from being the main point of the trips.Instead, the First Minister focused on trying to paint the UK Government in the worst possible light, and her own, as ever, as a shining example of all that is good. No matter, it seems that, the SNP consistently misses its own targets in the critical public services that are supposed to be its priority, just as long as its leader can get onto the world stage and seek to undermine the UK and our place within it.Keith Howell,White Moss, West Linton, Peeblesshire.CHRISTOPHER H Jonescontends that the SNP is "driven by Holyrood well, the Holyrood Parliament is elected by voters in Scotland, and accountable to voters in Scotland, unlike the position at Westminster where Scotland has a mere  seats out of . I must correct Mr Jones in his assertion that "dissent within the ranks" of the SNP is not permitted, as lively and robust debates are a feature of SNP branch, constituency and group meetings, but dferences of opinion do not become the open warfare we see raging within the two main unionist parties. Bitter internal squabblings in the Conservative and Labour parties have now boiled over, at least a dozen MPs have left their parties, more are expected to leave, and others, including government ministers, are threatening to leave.Mr Jones argues that within the Unionist parties "whilst some members may be disenchanted with a party position at least they are free to go their own way" indeed, they have gone their own way right out of their parties and formed their own group. The reality is that both Labour and the Tories are in not so much as a deep hole as a bottomless pit, and no amount of digging will get them out of it.Ruth Marr, Grampian Road, Stirling.IT would be instructive for those supporting the status quo of government to think carefully of the rules by which certain "democratic decisions have been made or rather concocted, and which are a backdrop to the present growing appeal of Scottish independence.In  the conditions for the Scottish devolution referendum were imposed by Westminster. Briefly, the determining factor was thatless than  per cent of the eligible electorate voted Yes, the Act of  which determined the referendum, would be repealed. The Yes vote was . per cent but with a turn-out of  per cent the resultant Yes vote was . per cent of the eligible electorate and the Act was repealed. This electoral contrivance is unique, and contrasts spectacularly with that governing the EU referendum of  and even more spectacularly with the usual rules of UK General Elections.In , when account is taken of the turn-out in the General Election, the Conservative Party achieved less than  per cent support of the eligible electorate and less than  per cent of the actual vote, but under the Westminster rules it formed the minority government, albeit having bought the ldquocourtesy of the DUP.In  the Yes vote to leave the EU was . per cent but after factoring in the turn-out of  per cent the Yes vote becomes . per cent of those eligible.In  the Yes vote in the Scottish referendum was similarly . per cent.The conclusion that only an independent Scotland with its own written constitution will be able, in its own interest, to unscramble the rules by which the Westminster establishment protects its position is plain to see.J Hamilton,G , Jackson Place, Bearsden.Read more: Catriona Stewart on Nicola Sturgeons trips

title: from-paisley-to-indiana-scottish-sculptor-unveils-epic-new-work-for-the-university-of-notre-dame
story: The towering, ft sculpture of Leon Battista Alberti, one of the giants of Italyrsquos Renaissance, is currently in the studios of Alexander Stoddart in Paisley, waiting to be cast in bronze and cross the Atlantic to its ultimate destination.The sculpture of the Italian architect, writer, poet and author is to be part of one of the USrsquos leading universities, the Universityof Notre Dame in Indiana.There, the towering figure will be part of a rebuilt architecture department.The sculptor, whose studios are located within the Paisley campus of the University of the West of Scotland, has shared an image of the sculpture, being worked on by studio assistants Lindsay McQuarrie and Zoe Roy.With iders in one hand, and a scroll in the other, Alberti, Mr Stoddart said, is looking at the remains of classical Rome - deep in the past - as well as looking into the future.In a detail which alludes to the Scottish site of its creation, Albertirsquos left leg is beside a Roman altar, to Diana and Apollo, which is part of the Hunterian Museumrsquos collections at the University of Glasgow.The plaster statue will shortly be move to Black Isle Bronze, where it will be cast in bronze, before itrsquos y shipped journey across the Atlantic: it is due to be unveiled officially at the University of Notre Dame in the summer.Mr Stoddart, known for his neo-classical sculptures - including David Hume and Adam Smith on the Royal Mile in Edinburgh, said it is the result of around two years of work.ldquoHe has iders in his hand - he is measuring the world. He is staring at Rome, and that is what is there in that block by his leg - so he is looking  years back, but also to the future, back and forward at the same time.Mr Stoddart said he is also currently working on a figure, also for the US, that will be taller.The sculptor noted that the figure of Albert , simply clothed, is distant from the current ldquoimperium of modernism.The artist said that Notre Damersquos School of Architecture, established in , perhaps aptly, emphasises traditional architectural ideals and theories.The architect John Simpson has designed the universityrsquos new School of Architecture building, and has worked with Mr Stoddart before, notably the Queenrsquos Gallery at Buckingham Palace.Mr Stoddart, born in , studied at Glasgow School of Art and the University of Glasgow.

title: mark-smith-the-five-big-hurdles-the-new-bbc-channel-is-going-to-have-to-overcome
story: This problem with young people has been one of the biggest issues on the minds of BBC producers as they prepare for the new channel and rightly so. The fact the young ones donrsquot watch TV in the way their parents do poses an existential threat to broadcasters, particularly a broadcaster like the BBC that expects everyone to pay for channels eventhey donrsquot watch them. Ironically, the people who do still watch terrestrial TV every day ndash the over s ndash are the only ones who donrsquot have to pay the licence fee.Read more:TV REVIEW: Is the new BBC Scotland channel magic or mince The BBCrsquos response to this problem has been to come up with ideas for the new channel that are firmly aimed at under s. Last night, for example, there was a show presented by Iain Stirling of Love Island. There was also a programme that had a whf of Channel  reality-show about it: Getting Hitched Asian Style. The only old fogies on opening night were Jack and Victor, but even their show, Still Game, is a big hit with the under s.Read more: The Question Time row raises profound questions for the BBCThe big question is whether this strategy is going to work and I have my doubts. Recently, I spent a few days with my godchildren who are aged between nine and , and what was striking about how they spent their time was that they didnrsquot switch on the BBC. Not once. For someone like me, or anyone  in their s who grew up with Basil Brush and Blue Peter, thatrsquos pretty extraordinary: young people arenrsquot watching the BBC regularlyat all. The question is: will they change their habits as they get older or is it the BBC that will have to change For the moment, the makers of the new channel are proceeding on the basis that they can still attract young viewers. But whether they can or not is just the first of the hurdles the channel is going to have to overcome, the second being whether they can attract an audience in the way that matters. In the old days, TV was about overnight viewing figures ndash bums on seats ndash but the director of BBC Scotland, Donalda MacKinnon, has already been managing expectations by saying the new channel will not be about the size of the audience. Thatrsquos not-very-subtle code for: the traditional viewing figures for the new channel are going to be very low.The question is whether it matters and, in a way, it doesnrsquot because viewing figures are not as important as they once were - itrsquos just as important that a programme does well on iPlayer and social media. That means that, to prove its worth, the channel is going to have to do well online and produce programmes that are shared by a younger audience. The fact that one of the early programmes is about the make-up artist Jamie Genevieve is a clue to where wersquore going here ndash she has more than a million Instagram followers.Where it gets dficult is whether the BBC can rise to this challenge, which leads to the third hurdle: the balance problem. The BBC is proud of its policy on balance but, as I pointed out in my column on Question Time the other day, the BBCrsquos idea of balance has led it to the ludicrous position that, for every environmental scientist on TV, there has to be a climate-change denier. ldquoBalance can also lead to some very dull TV and thatrsquos not going to help the new channel get its news reports shared online. People increasingly like news with attitude whereas the BBC does sensible. Sensible doesnrsquot go viral.The fourth, and perhaps the biggest, hurdle for the new channel is also, in a way, the reason for its creation in the first place. For years, there was pressure from the SNP for a Scottish Six news programe and the new channel is the end result ndash in other words, itrsquos the BBCrsquos response to a political argument rather than audience demand. The problem for the BBC, though, is the Scottish nationalists who most loudly demanded change are also the least likely to watch the new coverage because of its perceived bias ndash most of the talk among this group is about the reasons they wonrsquot watch.Read more: Of course the BBC is biasedThe recent row over an alleged plant in the audience of Question Time has not helped in this regard. There has also been very little evidence that the BBC is willing to seriously consider whether theyrsquore getting it right on alleged bias. In fact, Hayley Valentine, the editor of the new Scottish Nine news programme, made the extraordinary statement that she did not know ldquoa single journalist who brought any bias to work with them which is anti-logic of the worst kind: BBC journalists have bias just like any other human does, which is why the BBC has rules to try to overcome it.The allegation of bias also has serious consequences for the Scottish version of Question Time which is doomed to death by a thousand nationalist cuts before it even starts. The programme also faces the fth and final hurdle, which is money. BBC Scotland has already admitted they cannot afford to take their Scottish Question Time around the country which will not only make the channel feel Glasgow-centric , it will highlight the fact that the new channel simply doesnrsquot have the money it needs.Can the new channel get over these hurdles  Possibly, but remember previous experiments by the BBC. BBC Choice, which included regional iations for Scotland ndash axed in . The Scottish version of Newsnight ndash axed in . Scotland , which had average viewing figures as low as , ndash axed after less than three years. Perhaps the new BBC channel will be dferent to all of those, but it has something of the same feel doesnrsquot it  An attempt to be dferent without any great ability to be interesting. An attempt to be Scottish when very few people are watching.

title: oscars-olivia-colman-wins-best-actress-for-the-favourite
story: The star of The Favourite triumphed over The Wersquos Close, as well as Lady Gaga, Melissa McCarthy and Yalitza Aparicio for an unexpected win at the ceremony, where Green Book was named best picture.Colman was visibly shocked as her name was called and was helped to her feet by her husband Ed Sinclair and co-star Emma Stone, who planted a kiss on her cheek.Taking to the stage, she said: ldquoItrsquos genuinely quite stressful. This is hilarious. I got an Oscar!ldquoOK, I have to thank lots of people. If, by the way, I forget anybody Irsquom going to find you later and Irsquom going to give you all a massive snog and Irsquom really sorryImight forget now."Any little girl thats practicing her speech on the telly, you never know."Congratulations to @TheAcademy winner for Best Actress Olivia Colman. #Oscars #TheFavourite pic hNphloHmdash The FavouriteFebruary , Payingtribute to her director Yorgos Lanthimos as well as Stone and fellow co-star Rachel Weisz, she added: ldquoYorgos, my best director and the best film, and with Emma and Rachel, the two loveliest women in the world to fall in love with, and to go to work with every day, I mean, you can imagine, it wasnrsquot a hardship.ldquoAnd to be in this category with these extraordinary women, and Glenn Closehellip yoursquove been my idol for so long and this is not how I wanted it to be and I think yoursquore amazing and I love you very much.She added that she hoped her children were watching and said: ldquoIf yoursquore not, then, well done, but I sort of hope you are. This is not going to happen again.ldquoAnd any little girl who is practising their speech on the telly, you never know. I used to work as a cleaner and I loved that job, I did spend quite a lot of my time imagining this.Green Book won the biggest prize of the night as the surprise winner of best picture, a category largely expected to go to Roma.The film about a black jazz musician and a white driver travelling through the segregated US deep south also won the best supporting actor Oscar for Mahershala Ali, as well as best original screenplay.Rami Malek was named best actor for his role as Freddie Mercury in the Queen biopic Bohemian Rhapsody and planted a passionate kiss on the lips of his girlfriend and co-star Lucy Boynton before making his way to the stage.Regina King took the best supporting actress prize for her role in If Beale Street Could talk, leading to the most erse group of acting winners in the history of the Oscars.Shallow from A Star Is Born was named best original song and Lady Gaga addressed her director and co-star Bradley Cooper as she collected the gong, saying: ldquoBradley, there is not a single person who could have sang this song with me but you. Thank you for believing in me.ldquoIf you are at home sitting on your couch and watching this now, all I can say is this is hard work. Men And A Lady #################################### pic oSCXtPTfmdash Mark RonsonFebruary , ldquoIrsquove worked hard for a long time. This is not about winning, what itrsquos about is not giving up. If you have a dream fight for it.ldquoItrsquos not about how many times you are rejected and how many times you fall down, itrsquos how many times you stand up and keep going.Cooper and Gaga also performed the song at the ceremony, with the pair looking intently into each otherrsquos eyes during the duet before Cooper sat next to her at the piano.History was made earlier in the night when Ruth Carter became the first black winner to collect the best costume design prize, while Hannah Beachler became the first black winner of the production design gong, both for their work on Black Panther.The Marvel superhero movie was also recognised for its original score."As artists, our job is to look where others dont.This responsibility becomes much more important in times when we are being encouraged to look away.Muchas gracias a Libo. Muchas gracias a mi familia.Muchas gracias a Meacutexico."-Alfonso Cuaroacuten#Oscarsmdash Netflix FilmFebruary , The black-and-white, Spanish-language film Roma won three prizes, collecting the best director prize for Alfonso Cuaron, best cinematography, also for Cuaron, and best foreign language film.Bohemian Rhapsody was the most awarded film at the ceremony, with prizes for Malek, film editing, sound mixing and sound editing.

title: traveller-discovers-python-in-shoe-after-landing-in-glasgow
story: The creature was discovered in a shoe which had been packed away by a traveller from Stirling.The Bridge of Allan localmade the startling discovery after arriving home from GlasgowAirportafter which she alerted the Scottish SPCA.The travellers son-in-law Paul Airlie told local news siteABC Radio Brisbane: ldquoShe was not at all expecting to find the snake when she was unpacking a bag when she got back to Scotland.Read more:Winner of the wildle photo of the year revealedldquoShe had woken up a few days before she left and thought she had seen a snake in her room and woke me up at : in the morning to check.ldquoObviously she just picked the shoe up and stuck it in the bag and then it was there.ldquoSomehow or other it got from Mackay to Glasgow without being detected.Paul said the incident was reported to the Scottish SPCA.Scottish SPCA animal rescue officer Taylor Johnstone told theEvening Times: ldquoI can confirm we removed a snake from a property in Bridge of Allan.ldquoI responded to a call from a woman who had just ed from a holiday in Australia who had found a small snake inside her shoe in her suitcase. ldquoWhen I arrived, the snake had been contained by the caller, so I safely removed the snake from the property. ldquoUpon examination, the snake was found to be a spotted python which is not venomous.ldquoThe snake is now in quarantine at our animal rescue and rehoming centre in Edinburgh.

title: tony-blair-brexit-is-boosting-the-case-for-independence
story: The former Labour Prime Minister said it was ldquoabsolutely bloody obvious to him thatScotland were wrenched out the EU against its will it would help the Yes movement.ldquoIt doesnrsquot mean to say I agree with it, but itrsquos bound to have an impact, he said.In an interview with Holyrood magazine, Mr Blair also said that Scotland might be independent alreadyhis government hadnrsquot introduced devolution  years ago.He said the creation of a Scottish Parliament provided an ldquoalternative to independence and thatit didnrsquot exist, the UK might have broken up instead.:Labour failed in Scotland because it gave up the middle ground says Tony BlairAsked whether he understood why Scotland had voted so dferently from the rest of the UK in the EU referendum, he said: ldquoYes, because I think the degree to which this was driven by a sense of English nationalism, itrsquos obviously going to be more powerful in England than Scotland, and also because I think Scotland is quite comfortable with a European identity.He acknowledged Brexit may have made independence more likely.ldquoIrsquom not saying it will happen, because I still think there are very strong arguments against it, and obviously Irsquom not in favour of it, even after Brexit,we do Brexit.ldquoBut you know, I think when I said this before people criticised it, but it seems to me absolutely bloody obvious,Scotland is in favour of staying in Europe, and you wrench the UK out of Europe, then yep, people who are arguing for independence are going to have another dimension to their argument.ldquoIt doesnrsquot mean to say I agree with it, but itrsquos bound to have an impact.ldquoThe thing thatrsquos most frustrating to me about politics today is that wersquore not arguing about the right thing. Wersquore arguing about national identity, when it really isnrsquot the answer to anything, it really isnrsquot.Scotland voted - Remain in , while the UK as a whole voted - Leave.Mr Blair also admitted that he had over-estimated the power of devolution to dampen calls for independence, and wished Scotland and the UK had stayed ldquomore culturally aligned.Mr Blairrsquos former shadow Scottish Secretary George Robertson famously said in the s that devolution would kill Nationalism ldquostone dead.:Keith Brown: Scottish independence offers opposite of Brexit chaosMr Blair told Holyrood: ldquoUltimately, I think we overestimated, for sure, the degree to which devolution would quash independence, thatrsquos correct hellip But I think were it not for Brexit now, probably the mood in Scotland would be less in favour of independence than for some time.He added: ldquoI thinkI had any regret, I would have looked at more ways to keep Scotland and the UK feeling more culturally aligned.ldquoBut having said that, I think people forget that there was a huge amount of pressure for devolution as an alternative to independence andwe hadnrsquot offered that alternative, you might have had an independent Scotland by now.Deputy SNP leader Keith Brown said: "Make no mistake, Scotland having some powers has been good for Scotland. However today the debate is now fundamentally dferent from what was asked in ."The foundations of Westminster politics are crumbling, with Labour and the Tories choosing to ignore Scotlandrsquos voice and disregard the will of our Parliament, as they fixate themselves on bitter party infighting."Itrsquos clear that the case for independence is more compelling than ever. While Brexit offers small minded isolationism, independence is about Scotland taking its place on the global stage as an equal partner.

title: theresa-may-speech-live-pm-speaks-amid-calls-to-delay-brexit
story: Theresa May has insisted that it is "within our grasp" for Britain to leave the EU with a deal on March , as she resisted pressure for an extension to the two-year negotiation process.European Council president Donald Tusk revealed that he had discussed the legal and procedural process for extending withdrawal talks under Article  with the Prime Minister when he met her on Sunday in Egypt.Mr Tusk said that he believes delaying the UKs withdrawal beyond March  is now a "rational solution", warning that the only alternative,MPs cannot agree a deal, is "a chaotic Brexit".
