title: brexit-deal-within-our-grasp-claims-theresa-may-as-she-sets-her-face-against-extending-article-50
story: Her comments came just moments after Donald Tusk described extending the Article  process as a ldquorational solution to the current UK-EU impasse, warning that the only alternativeMPs could not agree a deal, was "a chaotic Brexit".The European Council President revealed he had discussed the legal and procedural process for extending the withdrawal talks when he met the Prime Minister in Egypt yesterday.Read more:Tony Blair: Brexit is boosting the case for independenceEU officials are said to be considering the option of a delay to exit day not just for a few months as some UK ministers have suggested but until  so that more talks can eliminate the need for the contentious Irish backstop.Pressure is mounting at Westminster from within and outwith the Conservative Party and, indeed, from within the Government itself, for Mrs May to delay withdrawal as MPs prepare to vote for such a proposition tabled in a binding amendment to Wednesdayrsquos debate in the Commons by Labourrsquos Yvette Cooper.But, speaking during a press conference at the EU-Arab summit in Sharm el-Sheikh, the PM insisted extending Article  would not address the issues facing Britain over its departure from the EU.ldquoA delay in this process does not deliver a decision in Parliament, it doesnrsquot deliver a deal what it does is precisely what the word says, declared Mrs May, who has had a raft of meetings at the Red Sea resort, including with Germanyrsquos Angela Merkel, Irelandrsquos Leo Varadkar and the European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker.Read more:She told journalists: ldquoI have a real sense from the meetings I have had here, conversations I have had with EU leaders in recent dayshellipwe can achieve that deal. Itrsquos within our grasp to leave with a deal on March  and thatrsquos where all our energies are going to be focused.The PM, who has put off having a meaningful vote this week but promised one by March , admitted there was ldquostill more work to do.But she noted: ldquoWhat I have sensed in all of my conversations with my fellow leaders both here in Sharm el-Sheikh and in recent days is a real determination to find a way through, which allows the UK to leave the EU in a smooth and orderly way with a deal.AskedCabinet ministers Amber Rudd, Greg Clark and David Gauke, who have suggested they could back Ms Cooperrsquos amendment, would have to resignthey did so, Mrs May brushed aside the question.She said: ldquoFirst of all, we have not laid the motion for Wednesday yet, we have not had amendments to that motion, we donrsquot know what amendments are going to be selected for debate.The PM confirmed she would be giving MPs an update on the Brexit talks tomorrow, saying she would tell them: ldquoWe will be making clear we have been making progress, we have had positive and constructive discussions. When we next bring the meaningful vote, itrsquos important people focus on whether we want to deliver on the result of the referendum and do that in a smooth and orderly way by leaving with a deal.Stephen Barclay, the Brexit Secretary, and Geoffrey Cox, the Attorney General, will be back in Brussels tomorrow for more talks with EU officials.The three Cabinet ministers wrote in a joint article at the weekend: "If there is no breakthrough in the coming week, the balance of opinion in Parliament is clear: that it would be better to seek to extend Article  and delay our date of departure rather than crash out of the European Union on March .They added: "It is time that many of our Conservative parliamentary colleagues in the ERG recognised that Parliament will stop a disastrous no-deal Brexit on March . If that happens, they will have no one to blame but themselves for delaying Brexit."Responding to Mrs Mayrsquos latest remarks, Labourrsquos Jo Stevens for the pro-EU Best for Britain campaign said: ldquoFrom the Prime Minister that brought us Brexit means Brexit, Maybot is now claiming that any delay is a delay.ldquoWhile the tectonic plates are shting on Brexit, the Prime Minister continues to have her fingers in her ears. It is shameful that May is holding the country to ransom by toying with a clf-edge Brexit.She added: ldquoItrsquos time for the Government to do the right thing and put the country first. The people want their voice back on Brexit.

title: bitter-legacy-of-miners-strike-sees-just-two-ex-cops-speak-in-public-to-inquiry
story: The low-turnout, a sign of the lasting bitterness around the dispute, is revealed in the interim report of the independent review, which also said its final findings would be delayed from June to August.The atmosphere at public hearings was ldquonot necessarily conducive for retired police officers to share their experience and recollections, it admitted.The situation has forced the review to rely on written evidence and private meetings with former officers instead.:Independent review ordered into policing during the s miners strikeEncouraged by the Retired Police Officers Association Scotland, some retired senior officers directly involved in policing the strike came forward, with a further meeting due this month.The investigation was set up under Solicitor Advocate John Scott QC last June to report on the impact of police tactics during the strike of  and .The period remains infamous for heavy-handed police action against pickets as Tory PM Margaret Thatcher fought the National Union of Mineworkers led by Arthur Scargill.The reviewrsquos interim report said  people attended eight public meetings late last year in Ayrshire, Clackmannanshire, Fe, Lanarkshire, Midlothian, Stirlingshire and West Lothian.It said: ldquoWe heard powerful and moving testimony from iniduals and their families who had been very badly affected by the strike, especially those who were arrested, charged, prosecuted, convicted and sentenced.ldquoMany lost their jobs, with their employers appearing to take a policy decision to dismiss regardless of the gravity of the allegation or the penalty imposed.ldquoSome of these men secured employment where, sometimes quickly but sometimes only after years. Some, especially because of having to declare their conviction, were unable to find other jobs. For some iniduals and their families, the lasting damage was obvious.It added: ldquoAt these meetings, perhaps unsurprisingly, very few speakers identied themselves as retired police officers although two speakers did so, and their contributions assisted in addressing some of the issues which recurred as themes at all of the meetings.:Review of miners strike policing calls for evidenceThe review also took more than  written submissions, including from miners and officers.SNP Justice Secretary Humza Yousaf, who agreed to a short extension to allow the review to write up its findings, said: ldquoScotland is leading the way in ensuring the experiences of those affected by the policing of the dispute in the s are properly heard and understood."I welcome the interim report and in particular the positive engagement undertaken with key iniduals, representative organisations and those employed in the mining industry and police at the time, their wider families and communities.ldquoA final report, setting out lessons learnt and making recommendations for any other action required, will follow at the end of the summer and be made publicly available.ldquoIt is important that we recognise the generous contributions made to the review by those who were affected. I want this review to bring openness, understanding and a degree of closure to all those involved.Mr Scott added: ldquoWhen we started our work on this important review, we decided that we should seek out as much direct evidence as possible from those who were involved in, and affected by, the minersrsquo strike.":Minersrsquo strike call is sheer opportunismLabour MSP Neil Findlay, whose campaigning helped secure the review, said: ldquoMining communities across Britain suffered at the hands of politicised and often brutal policing as Margaret Thatcher and her Tory Government used the power of the state to crush working people.ldquoThe review of these convictions should consider pardons to ensure those who were wrongly convicted finally get justice."GreenMSP John Finnie MSP added: ldquoTherersquos a clear link between the concerns being addressed by this group and the ongoing disquiet about UK undercover police officers who spied on countless political campaigns, stealing citizensrsquo identities along the way.ldquoI believe the Scottish Government should take a similar approach with those matters and instigate a public inquiry into historic UK undercover policing in Scotland, similar to the Pitchford Inquiry in England and Wales, and I urge Mr Yousaf to do so urgently.

title: new-bbc-scotland-digital-channel-was-the-third-most-watched-on-sunday-night
story: The high point of audience interest was Still Game, which attracted almost , viewers - the BBC say this is the highest ever ratings for a digital channel in Scotland.Across the evening of its first broadcast on Sunday night, BBC Scotland had an average audience share of %, making it the third most watched channel, behind BBC One and ITV.The broadcaster said it also reached more of  to  year olds than any other channel.Overall the new channel registered five out of the top ten most watched programmes across all channels in Scotland ndash Still Game, two episodes of A Night at the Theatre, Burnistoun Tunes In and The Peoplersquos News.Between pm and midnight, BBC Scotlandrsquos share moved ahead of ITV, making it the nd most watched channel during this time, the BBC said.The figures were calculated by BARB, the Broadcasters Audience Research Board.Steve Carson, the head of multi- commissioning for BBC Scotland, said: "This is a strong start for the new channel and wersquore delighted that viewers have come to us in such signicant numbers for our opening nightrsquos schedule."Our aim is to build a channel which resonates with audiences across Scotland through relevant and compelling content."We appreciate that ratings will settle down over time, but we are encouraged by the very positive audience feedback that wersquove had for our first night.The first night opened with a specially commissioned short film featuring Scottish band Chvrches and the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra.Chvrches singer Lauren Mayberry was the first voice to be heard on the channel, performing the bands song Miracle accompanied by images of Scottish people, places and landscapes.

title: tv-review-move-over-piers-morgan-alan-partridge-is-back-a-ha
story: ON being asked by an interviewerhe was ever tempted to stray during his marriage, Paul Newman famously inquired why he should go out for hamburger when he had steak at home.In the same vein, is there a place for a new Alan Partridge series in a world where Richard Madeley and Piers Morgan exist The answer came with the first giggle raised by This Time with Alan Partridge, and for half an hour the yucks kept coming, like zombie apes queuing up to play monkey tennis. If we must have one borderline bonkers television presenter with an ego visible from space then it has to be the original and best. Sorry, Piers. Suck it up, Ricardo.Marianne Taylor: BBC better off without NeilWhen we meet Alan again he is filling in for a poorly colleague on a programme not a million miles from The One Show. His co-presenter, Jennie , steals his jokes and rolls her eyes at every opportunity, and there were lots. ldquoIrsquom a married woman, said Jennie as he flirted with her, live on air. ldquoI was told you were separated, was Alanrsquos attempt at a witty rejoinder.There were some sharp jabs at the fly-by-the-seat-of-your-pants live television, with a mistake corrected by a tweet which was subsequently amended by an email. Mostly, though, the focus was Alan. His twitching. His chinos. His tie pin. The man is an emotional grenade.Book review: Limmy at his bestSome things did not work. The set was too big, though this did lend itself to a Spinal Tap-style walk by Alan in the worldrsquos noisiest shoes. But for the most part, Coogan, plus fellow writers Neil and Rob Gibbons, were on top form. Sidekick Simon was back with a ldquodigiwall that he could not operate Alan was heckled in traditional fashion while out filminghis assistant Lynn hates Jennie. It is going to end in tears, but of the good kind.ldquoDo you think Paul McCartney is watching this  Alan, needy as a newborn, asked Lynn. If he isnrsquot, hersquos a mug.

title: oscars-review-no-hosts-means-less-in-jokes-more-music-intrigue-and-politics
story: All that happened was we had a few less egos and baffling in-joke monologues leaving viewers to concentrate on what the Academy Awards are all about, star watching.The headline acts of the  Oscars were an array of the great and the good of the movie industry desperate to get their hands on a gold statuette, rather than a comedian whose humour often did not translate to a worldwide audience. Jimmy Kimmel may be a big name in the US but means little where yet was the host in .That might have been a reason why the ceremonys live audience last year was the lowest in in Oscars history, averaging . million viewers, down from . million in .What we ended up with was a st Academy Awards ceremony that felt less bloated but actually ran for about the same three-houras its predecessors.In the absence of a monologue, the ceremony kicked off with original Queen members Brian May and Roger Taylor rolling back the years, joined by Adam Lambert for a mini-medley of the bands classic songs featuring We Are The Champions and We Will Rock You, bringing the star-studded Oscars audience to its feet.It was the music rather than the laughs that stole the show.The immaculately choreographed performance of the Oscar winning original song Shallow by actor director Bradley Cooper and singer actress Lady Gaga was perhaps the most memorable moment of the night.With cameras placed at the back of the stage, the curtain lted and crew pusha grand piano into place with an array of blinding headlamps kissing the empty stage leaving viewers wondering what on earth was going on.Then the duo stephand-in-hand from their seats in the audience, Cooper helping Lady Gaga, whose shimmering, sleek Celine dress was a potential hazard, up the stairs to the stage.With the TV audiencestill with a back-of-stage view, Cooper sings, and Gaga stands staring into his eyes before taking her position behind the piano to play her part in this most intimate of love songs.Cooper then joins her on her piano stool and they become cocooned, steamily cheek to cheek for the denouement. It all feels so spine-tinglingly real, you do wonder what was going through the mind of Coopers partner, Russian supermodel Irina Shayk.They exitto a standing ovation, but it was, of course, meat and drink for the gossipmongers. Even Spice Girl Mel B who was a guest on the special broadcast said she was left feeling ldquouncomfortable for Coopers girlfriend.It was of course, supposed to be an act, an exercise of romantic artice, and a spin on their starring roles in the Star Is Born remake. If you like, it was four minutes encapsulating what moviemaking is about - making you believe.The laughs were less scripted.British actress Olivia Colman has come a long way from the days of her understated role as a scruffy and unstable love interest of the socially awkward and despondent loan manager played by David Mitchell in Peep Show.Since then she has become a serial winner of awards for her acting culminating in her first, surely of many, best actress Oscar for her role as as Queen Anne, the erratic and gout-ridden monarch in The Favourite.Her endearingly scatterbrained and scattergun speech has to go down as one of the most bizarre, emotional yet hilarious acceptances in recent years.She began by wiping the tears from eyes and said: "Ooooh, its genuinely quite stressful... this is hilarious. Got an Oscar."In a typicallyoff-the-cuff acceptance speech, Colman said she wanted to ldquothanks lots of people and thatshe forgot anyone she would find them later and give them ldquoa massive snog.Colman said how shocked she was to be there, having once worked as a cleaner and then blew a raspberry as she was asked to wind up.She also thanked Glenn Close, who was widely tipped as the likely best actress winner, saying she had been ldquoher idol for so long this is not how I wanted it to be.She went on to thank her children Finn,  and Hall, , adding she ldquohopes they are at home and watching, because ldquothis isnrsquot going to happen again.The Oscars have major flaws, of course, and viewers have to swallow the conceit that the best movies appear to be American.And, of course, the winning films are often worthy and issue-driven with action blockbusters, comedy and horror barely getting a look in.. So the best picture winner was race relations drama Green Book and included among the eight nominated best picture gongs are BlacKkKlansman, a movie about an African-American detective inflitrating the Ku Klux Klan, and Roma, a Mexican drama about the Mexican director Alfonso Cuaroacuten upbringing in the Colonia Roma neighborhood of Mexico City.Its asthe Academy are making a conscious effort to love Mexico in the midst of Donald Trumps determination to pledge to build a border wall.If that was not obvious politicisation over art, then Spike Lees comments while accepting the Best Adapted Screenplay award for BlacKkKlansman definitely was.He implored Americans to praise ancestors "stolen from Mother Africa" who have "built this country into what it is today along with the genocide of its native people".He said during Sunday nightrsquos ceremony: ldquoThe  presidential election is around the corner. Letrsquos all mobilise. Letrsquos all be on the right side of history. Make the moral choice between love versus hate. Letrsquos do the right thing.Trump, who is on his way to a summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un in Vietnam, responded with a personal jab on Twitter saying: ldquoBe niceSpike Lee could read his notes, or better yet not have to use notes at all, when doing his racist hit on your president, who has done more for African Americansthan almost any other pres!The controversy over Lee did not end there. He would later declare ldquothe ref made a bad call when Green Book won and reportedly tried to storm out of the Dolby Theatre after the announcement.Green Book, based on a true story of the friendship between a black pianist and his white driver touring the racially segregated deep south during the s, also won for best original screenplay and supporting actor, Mahershala Ali.In the press room backstage, Lee recalled that his film Do the Right Thing had failed to earn a best picture nomination for the Oscars in , the year that Driving Miss Daisy ndash about a black chauffeur for a white elderly southern woman ndash won the award.ldquoIrsquom snakebit. Every time someone is driving somebody, I lose, Lee said.The director, a fan of the New York Knicks basketball team, said when he heard Green Book announced as the yearrsquos best picture winner: ldquoI thought I was courtside at the [Madison Square] Garden, and the ref made a bad call.

title: tv-review-marks-out-of-10-for-bbc-scotlands-the-nine
story: Still, here we were, the evening after the channel launch the night before, with flagship news programme The Nine about to make its debut with anchors Rebecca Curran and Martin Geissler.But no pressure, people.It was such a big deal London had sent network media editor Amol Rajan to Glasgow to explain to the rest of the UK why pound million of their licence cash was being spent on this new channel. Something about decades of pressure and dissatisfaction with coverage of the independence referendum, apparently.But no pressure, people.No pressure, either, about launching this new bulletin in Scotland, the country that watches more BBC than other parts of the UK but is the least satisfied with what it sees. The new show had a few tests to pass. First, how many people watched  On Sunday, Still Game pulled in an impressive , viewers. Second, did the programme break its own stories  The team has had months to prepare, andthere was ever a time to put some goodies in the shop window it was now. Did it run smoothly, and was it dferent enough, and Scottish enough, to satisfy those who wanted a Scottish Six Is new channel magic or mince Before we arrive at some answers, the important stuff: what were the spring-autumn combo wearing  Geisslerrsquos outfit was Status Quo meets the designer shirt section in John Lewis. Curran had gone for a simple top and trousers coupled with heels so high they made her crossing of the set a thing of wonder and terror. I predict flatties by Thursday. As for the set, a large box in the centre of BBC HQ in Glasgow, it looked like the cell they placed Hannibal Lecter in before he escaped.The first item was Labourrsquos backing of a second EU referendum. With the story breaking around pm, the show had a real opportunity to steal a march on its pm competitors, but despite going to dedicated correspondents in Westminster and Brussels, nothing new emerged.Labours backing for second voteBack in the studio, both Curran and Geissler tackled Labour MSP Neil Findlay over Jeremy Corbynrsquos shting position on Europe. The interview was shouty and unedying, with lots of pen pointing and talking over each other, and that was just the anchors. Findlay wisely left them to it and sailed serenely on.The exclusive report duly arrived and it was into the buying of cheap, potentially deadly pills on social media. Scotland and a drugs story: jeez, what were the chances of that Next was an update on the investigation into the death of Kirsty Maxwell in Benidorm, including an interview with her father. This was followed by a report on medication to prevent HIV infection, then it was over to James Cook, chief news correspondent, in Reykjavik, where he was asking tourists their views on Brexit. So far, so unremarkable.But Cook had also landed an interview with the countryrsquos Prime Minister, Katrin Jakobsdottir, who spoke well on what it was like to be an independent country yet still have a trading relationship with the EU. This was more like it: an item with obvious relevance to Scotland tackled in an intelligent, engaging way.Sports presenter Amy Irons had a joint interview with Alex McLeish and Gregor Townsend about the pressures of managing the national teams, which was going fine till the anchors joined the trio on the sofa and, as with the Findlay interview, the conversation became garbled. BBC over-manning strikes again.The lighter stuff at the end was tired. The disappearing Scottie dogs story had been in the Sunday and Monday papers, ditto the interview with the young Scot who won The Greatest Dancer on Saturday. The last item, about the Oscars, must have been terribly interesting to the one person left on Earth who did not know Olivia Colman had won best actress.Come pm it had been a busy hour but a long one. This was a competent but underwhelming debut. It didnrsquot feel fast moving and agenda setting or whatever the hype had promised. Nor, the Cook report aside, was it very Scottish. The Nine will have to live a little more dangerouslyit is to score more marks out of ten than this.

title: crossing borders with your dog after brexit
story: A. The answer to this all depends on whether we leave the EU with or without a deal and when you want to travel.Pet passports wont be valid with a no deal BrexitAt the minute, you are supposed to have a pet passport for your dogtheyrsquore travelling from the UK to the EU and vice versa, although it is my understanding that there are no checks on pets crossing the Republic or Ireland and Northern Ireland border at the minute. Pet passports list the dferent treatments your pet has had and ensures they are microchipped and up to date with their rabies vaccine.Read more: JD Wetherspoon favours more UK products as Brexit moves closerThe passport means your pooch wont have to go into quarantine on arrival.If the UK leaves without a deal, then the rules will change and pet passports issued in the UK would no longer be valid.In this case, pet owners would need to get a health certicate - and the bad news is, this will take at least four months. Your dog will need a rabies vaccine with blood samplestaken  days after the jab. You will then have to wait three months after the samples come back clear to get the health certicate.The best thing to do is contact your vet for the latest advice four months before you hope to travel. data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.carricktoday webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"CE marking after Brexit"  CE marking after Brexit viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "CARR | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "CARR | Article Teaser"

title: embroidery exhibition at heritage centre
story: The Garioch Heritage Centre in Inverurie will host the Embroiderer#s Guild Lest We Forget embroidery exhibition next week.The free exhibition will run at the centre from Tuesday, February  to Tuesday, March .In  the Guild in conjunction with SSAFAinvited its members to take part in the commemoration of the ending of WW a  years previously by producing one heart.The plan being that each heart would be included in at least one exhibition, ideally, as near to their home location.Thus making unique and thoughtful exhibitions to fulfil the hope of a generation not to be forgotten.Using cloth, thread and textile each heart interprets a unique story of comradeship, bravery, victory or setback told by those ing from the Great War or in their heartfelt letters to those back home.The hearts illustrate to a new generation the men and the animals that accompanied them the unorms worn and medals won the regiments that fought together and the family members fondly remembered the songs that kept their spirits high and the words they wrote to those back home. This is a one-off, not to be missed, opportunity to view the  Scottish Hearts in the North East of Scotland. The exhibition and Centre is open between am and pm from Tuesday to Saturday.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The competition will be held in Inverurie Town Hall"  Record entries for  School Glee Choir Challenge viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: msp backs bursary funding for stem roles
story: Career changers can now apply for a five-figure sum to support them while training to fill high-demand teaching roles in STEMsubjects.The move has been welcomed by Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin, a former college lecturer, who has previously backed encouraging more girls and women to take STEM subjects.A total of  bursaries are available in academic year   at a total cost of £ million - with Home Economics included for the first time.Applicants will be able to apply for a bursary of £,.Other STEM subjects in demand are Physics, Chemistry, Maths, Technical Education and Computing Science.Applications for bursaries have opened todayfor postgraduate teacher training courses beginning in August .Commenting, Gillian Martin MSP said: “This is a brilliant investment by the Scottish Government to help encourage more people to train in STEM subjects.“The development of skills in these subject areas will be vital for our future economy and will help to inspire the next generation of the Scottish workforce.“Bursaries like these will help to provide financial help and make it easier for people to make exciting career changes which will have an impact on pupils in the years ahead.”Skills Development Scotland Education Programme Lead Ken Edwards said: “The support offered by the STEM Bursary gives career changers the security to make the move from existing employment into teaching.“This will contribute to getting the right skills balance in the teaching workforce and in supporting young people to be engaged and enthused in their STEM learning.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..! title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Delay to Wick 20 mph speed limit plans
story: THE brakes have been put on plans to introduce a  mph speed limit on the majority of roads in Wick.The proposal was mooted by Highland Council as a way to improve road safety and encourage walking and cycling.However, Wick members of the Caithness committee this week described the scheme as "a blunt instrument" and said other measures to reduce speed would be more effective. They also felt the consultation period should be extended by three weeks to allow the public more time to respond to the plan.Speaking at the meeting in Wick Town Hall on Wednesday, Councillor Nicola Sinclair said she was "very much in favour" of improving road safety but was concerned about the scale of the  mph limit and claimed there should be a longer period of consultation."The consultation took place over the Christmas period and I dont think people got enough opportunity to get their views heard," she said.Full report in Fridayrsquos John OrsquoGroat Journal.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. He was unable to confirmMeghan would attend along with her husband, but said it would be ldquotruly fantastic for Caithness and help put it on the mapthe royal couple turned up.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will welcome their first child this spring.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Monday  Feb  : PM

title: Wick Francis Street Club placed in liquidation
story: WICKS Francis Street Club has been placed in liquidation, it was confirmed on Thursday.According to provisional liquidator Iain Fraser, a partner with FRP Advisory, the decision was made following a decline in membership, rising costs and unsustainable cash-flow problems. The club ndash founded in the s as a British Legion ndash has now closed and six staff have been made redundant.Mr Fraser said: "The Francis Street Club has been a landmark social, entertainment and sports venue in Caithness for nearly  years. Sadly, the club has been suffering severe financial problems and liquidation was the only option available to the committee."We are working closely with the relevant agencies, including the Redundancy Payments Office, to ensure the staff receive as much support as possible. We are now offering the assets of the business for sale, including the building, fixtures and fittings, and would urge interested parties to contact our Aberdeen office as soon as possible on   ."The Francis Street Club started was a long-established social, entertainment and sporting venue which attracted some well-known names through its doors, including former world snooker champion Stephen Hendry who staged an exhibition match there.It served as a social club and ran both football and darts teams, both well supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.The premises closed last month. At the time, a statement issued by the club said: "It was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , ."A note subsequently posted on the door read: "We have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course."Monday  Feb  : PM

title: accessibility top of the agenda for northlink
story: Changes are being made by NorthLink Ferries to make their services more accessible to all.On board information workshops and the introduction of new website software are the latest efforts being made by the company to improve services for those with additional support needs.The ferry operator implemented its new Recite Me accessibility tool on its website, this month, to make it more suitable to folk#s needs. The new software — which can be used on desktops and mobile browsers — allows website visitors to customise what they see and hear, from changing the contrast settings, language, font size and more.In the UK, there are estimated to be . million people with a learning disability and . million people who have English as a second language. ‘Recite Me’ has the ability to translate the NorthLink Ferries website into more than  languages — including Scots Gaelic . It can also translate text-to-speech to help visually impaired users and focus screen areas for those with dyslexia.On Monday, February , teams on board MV Hamnavoe hosted an Access Panel Orkney session, where staff were provided with disability awareness training. During the two-hour session, staff were able to experience what it’s like to have a disability by wearing glasses that simulated blindness, used wheelchairs and crutches and had their hearing dampened.Carolyn Grfiths of Access Panel Orkney said: “The aim of our session was to let staff experience disabilities first-hand so they can empathise with passengers’ needs.#All of us running the training have a disability so we were able to provide first-hand examples of what accessible travel is like for us. We were delighted to be welcomed on board to provide this training and it’s great to see a company like Serco NorthLink Ferries take accessibility for passengers seriously.”The MV Hjaltland will also host a Making Connections workshop today, Friday, February . The workshop will look at how passengers navigate potential barriers when changing from one mode of transport to another. Making Connections brings disabled people together with transport operators to discuss, address and plan how travel connections can be made easier.Seumas Campbell, customer service director at NorthLink Ferries, said: “Catering for passengers with ying degrees of disability is an important part of our service provision. Whether they are using our website to book their journey, making a connection from other forms of public transport or coming on board one of our vessels, we believe that passengers should experience a service that caters to all their needs.“The new website software will allow visitors to customise what they see and hear and as more and more visitors from around the world choose NorthLink Ferries to travel to the Northern Isles, ‘Recite Me’ is a great tool to help them plan and book their journey.“Our workshops are also a great way in training our staff on how they can best help and understand passengers’ needs. We pride ourselves on having a great team that always provides the best service so it’s important that we’re constantly refreshing their training.”For more information on accessibility for passengers on NorthLink Ferries, you can visit www.northlinkferries copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: alfred takes to the water in vietnam
story: PENTLAND Ferries and Strategic Marine Vietnam have announced the successful launch of the new vessel Alfred.At pm Vietnam time on Friday, well-wishers, invited guests, shipyard workers and Pentland Ferries team members lined the slipway as the completed hull of the ship rolled down the slipway and into the warm waters of where the vessel was built, Vung Tau, Vietnam.Since the keel was laid, approximately , tonnes of steel hull and aluminium superstructure have been welded together in a large workshop to create the flagship vessel for Pentland Ferries operations, named after Pentland Ferries managing director Andrew Banks# father Alfred Banks.The ship will carry  passengers and up to twelve lorries combined with  cars, or  cars in total.The final fit out of the interior will take place prior to a complete series of sea trials in Vietnam before Pentland Ferries crew sail Alfred back to home base in St Margaret#s Hope.Joseph Azran Alemberg SMV chief operating officer said: “Today’s a big day for Strategic Marine Vietnam and a proud moment for everyone that contributed to the vessel build. Strategic Marine and Pentland Ferries worked tirelessly in co-operation to bringing the project to fruition.”Andrew Banks said: “We are delighted to announce Alfred has been launched successfully and we are looking forward to getting the ship home to Orkney and into service.#The vessel, which had a breadth of m, and a draft of .m, has a top speed of  knots.The expected handover of the vessel to Pentland Ferries is at the end of March, with the delivery voyage set to take around six weeks weeks. It is hoped that the new vessel will be in service in June.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Presented over two floors, the generous accommodation comprises sitting room, dining room, living room, shower room, kitchen, utility room, laundry room and conservatory on the ground floor. On the first floor are five bedrooms and a bathroom. There is a staircase leading to the attic rooms which may offer the potential for further development with the appropriate permissions being granted.The generously proportioned living and sitting rooms each have a large bay window to the front of the property and with double doors leading from the living room into the dining room. The kitchen is fitted with a good range of units with an integrated dishwasher, fridge and a gas range and is situated adjacent to the conservatory, which in turn opens to the mature gardens . The utility and laundry rooms offer an ever friendly addition to the family home. The shower room and the bathroom are both wellappointed, with the bathroom having been recently refurbished. title: german fleet salvage sites archaeology project results published online
story: With the centenary of the scuttling of the German High Seas Fleet in Scapa Flow fast approaching in June of this year, a fascinating insight into remains of aspects of the wrecks has now been published online.Historic Environment Scotland commissioned the Orkney Research Centre for Archaeology and SULA Diving to complete a full survey of the wrecks and debris remaining on the sea bed following the inter-war salvage operations.The seven remaining ships of the High Seas Fleet have seen Scapa Flow become one of the most well-known e sites in the World. Those wrecks are still the primary focus of recreational ers, but the remains of the vessels that were mostly recovered and removed from Scapa Flow have also been a recognised ing resource for many years.However, the exact extent and composition of these so-called salvage sites was unknown until this week, when the report of the second phase of work on these sites was published online.The overall aim of the Scapa Flow Salvage Sites Project was to determine what remains of the many vessels of the German High Seas Fleet that were salvaged in the years that followed their scuttling in June .Phase One, undertaken over the winter of  , involved a side scan sonar survey of the main anchorages and other areas thought to have been involved in the salvage process.In the second phase of this project, ers and remotely operated vehicles examined and recorded the remains in detail.The overall result is that the vast majority of salvage sites in Scapa Flow have been located and the remains at each site have been directly investigated and recorded.The full report is now available for public download through the Scapa Flow Historic Wreck website http:www.scapaflowwrecks projects salvage-sites-phase- Further details in The Orcadian on Thursday.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: in the footsteps of dr john rae
story: Next month will see a group of intrepid adventurers undertake a -mile mission in the Canadian Arctic, retracing the footsteps of one of Orkney#s most renowned, yet also overlooked, sons — Dr John Rae.The Arctic Return expedition will see a four-man team set off from Naujaat — also known as Repulse Bay — in late March, aiming to retrace the footsteps made by the surgeon, explorer and surveyor in .It was on that expedition that the explorer finally discovered an open channel to the east of King William Island in the high arctic. Known today as Rae Strait, it was the missing link in what would become the first navigable Northwest Passage.He also reported back on the ill-fated Franklin expedition, reported evidence of cannibalism — findings which were effectively rejected by the then establishment, and which led to Rae#s achievements being almost completely ignored.The modern-day team, who hope to raise further awareness of these achievements, will be led by Scottish-born and Canada-based expedition leader David Reid, with Scotland also represented by Broxburn-based former Royal Marine Richard Smith.The team will also include two Canadians — adventure film-maker Gerry Tutte and adventurer Frank Wolf.Over  years later and supported with modern-day kit from outdoor specialists Tiso, the explorers are hard at work preparing for the physical and mental challenge of hauling kg sledges for nine hours daily and for up to  consecutive days.Their route will cover undulating, windswept tundra, river valleys and sea ice during what can be the coldest time of year.The Arctic expedition will finish once the four explorers have finally reached Gjoa Haven on King William Island.Mr Smith said: #The Arctic Return expedition will be extremely tough but ultimately our aim is to raise awareness fo the exploits of John Rae and to help restore his rightful place as one of the greatest Scottish explorers in history. It is also our hope that this awareness will inspire the public to support fundraising efforts by the John Rae Society, to restore Rae#s birthplace at the Hall of Clestrain in Oprhir.The team have said any addition funds raised are to be used to produce a documentary film and book about the le and exploits of Rae, the expedition and the history communities, culture and wildle of the Arctic.The public will be able to track the team#s progress at their official website and through social media.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: mcarthur welcomes fuel poverty re think
story: Orkney’s MSP, Liam McArthur has welcomed Scottish Government plans to ensure that its Fuel Poverty Bill recognises the higher costs faced by those living in remote rural and island areas.During the stage one debate in Parliament yesterday, Wednesday, the Housing Minister, Kevin Stewart indicated that he would bring forward amendments to the bill to include an ‘uplt’ to the minimum income standard for rural and island communities. Mr McArthur believes this reflects a change in approach by the government, after months of campaigning by the Orkney MSP and a range of organisations involved in tackling fuel poverty across the Highlands and Islands.During his remarks, Mr McArthur pointed out that when it comes to fuel poverty, rural and island areas are disproportionately affected, with Orkney having the highest proportion of households in fuel poverty and extreme fuel poverty anywhere in Scotland.Commenting after the debate, Mr McArthur said: “Fuel poverty blights communities across Scotland, but there is no doubt that it has a disproportionate impact on rural and island areas. Until recently, however, the Scottish Government appeared unwilling to recognise this fact or indeed the higher costs faced by those living in our rural and island communities.“Over recent months, working with a range of organisations with a wealth of experience and expertise in tackling fuel poverty, I have made the case for the Minister, Kevin Stewart to think again.  It was a case that the Local Government Committee was also persuaded to support.“I am delighted, therefore, that the Minister has had a change of heart and committed to bring forward amendments to his bill at stage two that better reflect the specic nature of fuel poverty in places like Orkney.  I look forward to seeing the detail of those amendments and will work with Mr Stewart, and local stakeholders in Orkney, to make sure we get this right.“Given the impact fuel poverty can have, not just on people’s quality of le but their physical and mental health, this bill has the potential to make a real dference.  For that to happen, it must be both effective and ambitious in eradicating fuel poverty from communities across the country.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: An Orkney College student will be one of  folk to represent Scotland at a special exhibition in Venice, Italy, this year.Jenny Sprenger has been selected to attend a professional development programme as part of the Scotland + Venice  exhibition during this year’s Biennale of Art in the city.Exhibition assistant Jenny will be given the opportunity to support Scotland’s presentation of new video work by Charlotte Prodger during the Biennale Arte  which runs from May to November.On being selected Jenny Sprenger said: “I am both thrilled and honoured to have been selected to be part of this opportunity, and I am looking forward to the chance to connect with other artists and see world-class contemporary art in the flesh.”Cove Park — an international artists residency centre based in Scotland — is spearheading the Scotland + Venice Professional Development Programme. title: Ambitious plan sets goals to end fuel poverty
story: PEOPLE across Ross-shire could benefit after the Scottish Government incorporated changes into its own draft legislation to ldquoend the scourge of fuel poverty.An earlier barrage of criticism claimed the Fuel Poverty Bill missed the target when it came to delivering for the ldquoworst affected areas.Fuel poverty is defined as when households spend  per cent or more of income on domestic fuel ndash reckoned to account for one in four homes in Scotland.The figure is understood to be signicantly higher across swathes of Ross-shire, hitting homes which are not on the gas grid and reliant on oil and low-income households.Minister for local government, housing and planning, Kevin Stewart, promised to include ldquoa rural, remote and island minimum income standard in poverty calculations as well as what he called ldquoa rural uplt.He was speaking at the first stage of a Holyrood debate of the Bill which aims to cut fuel-poor households to five per cent by  from the current national average of almost  per cent.The move was welcomed by rural housing associations and local councillors but Highlands Tory MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston vowed to maintain pressure on the government to deliver on what was promised.He said: "The minister announced that a new rural, remote and island minimum income standard will be included in their fuel poverty calculations alongside a rural uplt. We will be looking to strengthen the Bill as it progresses through the Scottish Parliament and ensuring that the Scottish Governmentrsquos pledges are met."Before Wednesdayrsquos debate Mr Stewart said: ldquoWithin this ground-breaking legislation, not only are we one of the few countries in the world to define fuel poverty, we are also setting a goal towards eradicating it.ldquoBy changing the definition of fuel poverty so itrsquos more closely aligned to relative income poverty and taking steps to ensure it works for remote rural and island communities, we are ensuring our support is focussed on those who need it most."He added: "In this day and age, it is unacceptable that any Scottish household should have to choose between having the heating on and cooking their dinner.Councillor Ian Cockburn, who represents the Wester Ross, Strathpeffer and Lochalsh welcomed the Bill as "something has to be done about fuel poverty" while arguing it is also time to rethink infrastructure like the national grid."It is ambitious but has to be tried to get fuel poverty down in rural areas. We are one of the most energy rich countries in the world so we should be able to get something done. Too many people take it as just being part of the landscape up here so we need to change that thinking as well to get people the assistance that they need."Scotland should not be in this state. But you have to look back, the National Grid was set up at the end of the war, the Highlands is considered off-grid despite supplying much of the rest of the country through hydro and wind power. It is time for a rethink."Calum Macaulay, chief executive of Invergordon-based Albyn Housing Society, said: ldquoWe welcome this development in the Scottish Governmentrsquos approach to addressing fuel poverty in rural areas. The push to include minimum income standards feels like a signicant step forwards. This is something that the Rural and Islands Housing Association Forum has been promoting for quite some time."This has included research undertaken with the support of Highlands and Islands Enterprise and others into minimum income standards in rural communities. The results of this highlighted the pressures of lower average household incomes and higher average fuel costs across the northern parts of Scotland."What do you think  Share your views by emailing newsdesk@spp-groupMonday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Black Isle authors French connection helps ensure nothing is lost in translation
story: Vee Walkers Major Toms War, partly set in France during WWI, is now fittingly being translated into French for a new edition of the book.Such has been the response to the novel that the Black Isle author has already been on a book tour and visited France on the back of it. The annual Franco-Scottish Society Alexander Gray Fund Lecture in Inverness on Friday promises to be alight-hearted bilingual talk from Ms Walker and her "long-suffering" Parisian translator Richard Kausch.Major Tomrsquos War is a moving novel set in France during the First World War, in part in the grim lsquozones occupeacuteesrsquo of northern France.Its characters are real people ndash and both author and translator have had to enter the minds of the novelrsquos key protagonists.The novel is published in English by Kashi House in London and the French edition should follow late this year or early in .Veeand Richard will be touring four of the regional Franco-Scottish Societies of Scotland this month.The groups exist to foster French language and culture in Scotland and meet monthly for French conversation or a lecture.Those who come along are welcome to join or to attend as a non-member. They are suitable for Higher Advanced Higher French pupils and their teachers.Vee confesses that as a French-speaking author she has not madeher translatorsle any easier: "Most translators produce a translation and the author would not have a clue about whether or not it is representative or accurate."My first degree was in French and although I am not a native speaker, I have had an opinion on nuance and vocabulary right the way through."Richard is currently revising the French text a second time to address the changes requested by my English publishers for the First Edition. He has the patience of a saint and I donrsquot know what I would have done without him!"Wersquore both looking forward to meeting audiences in Aberdeen, Edinburgh, Glasgow and Inverness on our tour around Scotland very much."Vee and Richardrsquos final tour slot is in Inverness on Friday, February  at the Glen Mhor Hotel,  Ness Bank, Invernessat .pm.Thelecture is free and will be followed by a French meal atpm. Theres a fixed menu.Reservations can be booked on   for lecture and or meal. Themeal is pound to members andpound to non-members.Monday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Call for flexibility over closure of Rosemarkie toilets
story: FEARS are intensying over the future of public toilets in Rosemarkie after Highland Council revealed that it would only keep them open until the end of March.The th hour news appears to fly in the face of assurances given to local community leaders at a meeting last November and has sparked a petition that has already got more than  signatures from worried locals calling for the council to keep the facility open.It had been hoped a charitable trust could be set up to take over the running of the facility, a process anticipated to take months, but time for that is running out and in the meantime it is feared harm could be done to the villagersquos appeal as a visitor destination.The well-loved and well-respected Groam House Museum could be impacted as well, with staff and visitors both needing to use the public convenience as there are no facilities on the premises.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoA draft temporary lease is being drawn up to enable the planned Community Development Trust to be taken forward. If the facility is not taken on by the community then it will close on March as per report to the Highland Council [on] October .ldquoNo survey will be undertaken, the facility will transfer in lsquoas seen, as isrsquo condition, the facilities will transfer in their current operational condition. The position of toilets remaining open whilst negotiations are ongoing is for this financial year only. There is no budget to retain facilities... which is why we want to get the leases sorted out before the end of March.Despite that the director of the Groam House Museum Doug Maclean, who recently attended a meeting of the community council where the future of the toilets was on the agenda remains hopeful.ldquoWe are confident that by some means or other, through a charitable trust taking over the running of the toilets and the good services of the local people, we will be able to keep the toilets open, he said.However, Mr Maclean was in no doubt about how serious an effect the closure would have on Rosemarkie as well as Groam House Museum.ldquoFrom the museumrsquos point of view it is absolutely vital for our existence. We have groups of school children that come here and of course children need to go to the toilet, he said.ldquoWe also have groups of mainly elderly American tourists and they are not in a position to make their way to the beach cafeacute. And we would lose both those groups without the toilets which put the museum in jeopardy.Black Isle ward councillor Gordon Adam said: ldquoI am in discussions with the council over the time limit of March , my view is that the council needs to be flexible. Savings have to be made, but sticking rigidly to a timetable leaves little time to form development groups.Monday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Climate action call comes to Inverness streets
story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. We could be on the brink of a mass extinction like the one which wiped out the dinosaurs.ldquoThe petition asked that the Highland Council... reverse inconsistent policies and work alongside the media to communicate with residents.The petition also called on the local authority to pass a climate emergency motion to make the region carbon neutral by .Fiona Cormie who has just taken on the role of co-ordinator of the group, said they hoped to add ldquosignicantly to its number of petition signatories in the coming weeks and present them to the council.Monday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Funding blow to Ross shire alcohol support service
story: ALCOHOLISM support in Ross-shire has been dealt a blow after a group that helps people fight addiction announced its closure ndash amid funding cuts and increasing red tape.The board of Alcohol Counselling Services Ross and Sutherland , which has been supporting people in the region for more than  years, has ldquosadly and regretfully decided that the service will close from April .News of the closure has been greeted with dismay by recovering addicts, one of whom, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that without the service their ldquooutcome could have been very dferent.Explaining the reasons for the closure, the servicersquos co-ordinator, Chris Cochrane, said: ldquoThis decision has not been taken lightly. There are many reasons why this course of action is necessary, the main one being the struggle to secure sufficient finances to run the organisation.About pound, to pound, is needed annually but Ms Cochrane said that the NHS is doing a review of third sector input, and can only confirm funding up to June.Without the support of the NHS, they will find it dficult to win the support of other funding bodies.The news will be a blow to the  service users currently on the books of ACSRS many of whom faced a personal battle before seeking help and then keeping on attending to receive the support on offer.However Ms Cochrane said they will do everything in their power to ensure their clients receive alternative assistance with their dependency. Around  people with alcohol dependency are referred to them each year.She said: ldquoThe board is actively pursuing alternative arrangements for our service users and volunteer counsellors who wish to continue their support or volunteering.ldquoACSRS has been indebted to many people over the years who have given their time and expertise freely as volunteers. Some have assisted in the management of the service as board members providing governance and support for staff and volunteers.ldquoOthers have given thousands of hours of their free time as trained volunteer counsellors. There are six counsellors and not all of them will be wanting to move on though some might seek paid employment.ldquoThe training for these counsellors was previously provided free. It now requires a source of additional funding.ldquoAs for other voluntary organisations, the burden of bureaucracy has increased without the corresponding increase in income, and the task of securing additional funding has become more challenging.ldquoACSRS is the only voluntary organisation within Ross-shire and Sutherland offering a free professional one-to-one counselling service for those affected by their own or a loved onersquos addiction. Our work complements the work done by NHS Drug and Alcohol Recovery staff.ldquoWe would like to thank all those people for their extremely valuable contributions which made it possible for us to serve our community for over  years.Councillor Margaret Paterson, Dingwall and Seaforth, said: ldquoI know this group and this will be a dreadful loss as they give a tremendous service. It is quite distressing to hear this because they have given people with addiction and their families such help for so many years. Their volunteers have given such time and talent to help the vulnerable in society, butthey donrsquot have money then they just canrsquot do it. I hope that something can be done to continue their good work.Two service users who wished to remain anonymous praised ACSRS for the help they received. One said: ldquoI can honestly say that ACSRS played a major part in my recovery. If that help was not there when I needed it, the outcome could have been very dferent.The other said: ldquoHearing a voice that was willing to listen to me was a relief on one of the darkest days of my le.Monday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Highland Council investing extra in roads maintenance
story: Highland Council is hoping an additional pound. million for maintenance announced as part of this yearrsquos budget will make a ldquonoticeable dference across the region.The funding, approved as a priority area for the revenue budget, will be shared out across Highland with area committees able to decide how to prioritise it more locally.Chairman of the councilrsquos environment, development and infrastructure committee, Councillor Allan Henderson, said: ldquoWe have the most extensive network of roads in the UK and, added to this, we are faced with some of the most severe weather conditions in the Highlands.ldquoThe freeze-thaw conditions in particular cause immense damage to road surfaces and this is very evident in the past few weeks.ldquoRoad conditions are a high priority for local residents and this was very clear in our recent engagement with communities and local representatives.ldquoThe additional resource will, I hope, make a noticeable dference and can be allocated to the roads with the most urgent need of repairs, right across the Highlands.Area allocations based on road mileage and population are:Badenoch  Strathspey: pound, Caithness: pound,Inverness: pound, Lochaber: pound, Nairn: pound,Ross  Cromarty: pound,Isle of Skye: pound,Sutherland: pound,Monday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Invergordon ports plans put on public display
story: MORE than  members of the public took the opportunity to get a closer look at the Port of Cromarty Firthrsquos ambitious poundm expansion plans.The public information event in the port offices in Invergordon on Wednesday afternoon also allowed visitors to ask questions about the scheme. The port says the expansion is needed to maximise opportunities in the renewable energy sector and the cruise ship trade.Port marketing manager, Joanne Allday, said the response to the plans had been very encouraging.ldquoWe wanted to let people know what was happening, she said.ldquoIt was lovely to see so many people attending and taking an interest. There were lots of questions about how the project would progress, but people were very positive about it. They can see the benefits it can bring.Work has already begun on the quayside construction and is expected to run until March next year.The additional space will be used to assemble turbines for the Moray East Offshore Windfarm, but will also allow Invergordon, which is already Scotlandrsquos busiest cruise port, to accommodate the largest cruise ships currently being designed and built.This is the second quayside expansion at Invergordon in three years.Monday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Joy as Ross shire students win film prizes
story: GAELIC students from Ross-shire are celebrating after they were honoured in a nationwide film competition.Eilidh Johnson , from Dingwall, and Tain Royal Academyrsquos Jack Weir and Gordie Bryce were among the winners in the annual Gaelic film competition, FilmG.And Ms Johnson, who studies at Sabhal Mograver Ostaig in Sleat on Skye, had double the reason to celebrate after picking up two titles from three nominations. Her thought-provoking film Glaiste, a stop-motion piece about mental health, won best mobile short and also earned her the title of HIErsquos most promising young director. Her work was also one of the shortlisted finalists for best student film.Jack Weir and Gordie Bryce, meanwhile, were named best young filmmakers for their film Fagraveisneachd Dedrickabout a businessman struggling to come to terms with his wersquos death.Ross-shirersquos impressive representation in the finals also extended to Alness Academy, which made the shortlist for the FilmG award for Gaelic learners with its effort Gaol anns arsquo Chogadh . The title ultimately went where in the Highlands, after Millburn Academy won with their gripping film, Unknowing.The annual short film competition began in . It is run by MG ALBA and Cagravenan Graphics and was established to help the development of Gaelic through film.Murdo MacSween, communications manager at MG ALBA, said: ldquoI am over the moon with the quality of the films at this yearrsquos awards. It is wonderful to see so much young talent nurturing their Gaelic language skills ndash and being rewarded for it.Elsewhere among the Highland winners was Inverness man Calum MacLean, who won best industry director for his experimental film Fo Bhuaidh. Mr MacLean is best known for his appearances on the BBCrsquos The Social  and BBC ALBArsquos wild swimming series Dhan Uisge.Monday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies.
